I remember the 14th of October very well—in the early part of that week, Levine called on me, and said he had got some calicoes to dispose of—he said he had sold some to Mr. Hallett, and he would call on me the next morning in his way down—on the 14th he came with Beamond, and brought two pieces of calico with him—he asked 4d. a yard for them—I said I should not buy them, I did not want them—I said if I took twelve pieces, they would take something less—Beamond then said 3 3/4 d.—I said if they would take an eighth off I would—I bought twelve pieces of one quality, at 3 1/2 d. and an eighth, that is 3 5/8 d., and they brought them down in the afternoon—I remember seeing the pieces on the counter, and the two prisoners were there—the lengths were taken, and I paid the money down to Levine—I wanted 2 1/2 per cent, off for cash, and he gave

me half-a-crown—I required an invoice—he came down the following day, and made the invoice out in my shop, on the back of one of my bills—this is it—he has given me discharge, "by cash, 10l. 11s."—this was on Friday, the 15th—he was without Beamond then—the inspector called on me, and nine whole pieces and three short lengths were given up to the police, but not in my presence—a part of them had been sold—I know them.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTONE. Q. How long have you known Levine? A. I think four or five months—I have known him as dealing in articles of this description—he gave me his own address, but not Ber
mond's—I did not ask him any thing about Beamond—I should think I gave a fair price for them—I sold them at 3 3/4 d. a yard—Levine told me he was the agent.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What have you known about Levine? A. No
thing more than as a commission agent—he called on me with goods, and referred me to parties in the neighbourhood, to Mr. Cadman, an iron monger, next door, and several others, whose names I did not notice.

EDMUND MANNING . I live in Aldgate High-street, and am a linen-draper. On the 13th of October, I purchased twenty-four pieces of calico of the prisoner Levine—I first saw him about them on Tuesday, the 12th, I believe—he told me he had some calico to sell, and he brought two piece the same day—he asked 4 1/2 d.—a yard for them—I declined to give that price for them—he asked me what I would give—I told him I did not want them, and would rather not have them—at least I said I would not give more than 3 1/2 d.—he turned round to Beamond who was with him, and they talked a little, and Beamond said, "Well, I shall get a farthing a yard"—then Levine said, "Very well, you shall have them"—he asked me how many I would have, whether I would have ninety pieces—I said no, I would have twenty pieces—I ultimately agreed to buy twenty pieces—they then went away—twenty-four pieces of calico came the next day, the 13th—I did not see who brought them—I saw a bale lying in the shop—I afterwards saw the prisoners on the same day—I said there were more than I ordered—one of the prisoners said, "Well, I suppose you will take them?"—I said, very well, as they were brought to me I would—I told Levine if he would make out an invoice and leave it, I would see if they were right—he then wrote out this invoice, and left it—Levine called in the afternoon—I paid him—Levine wrote this receipt—(read)—"Re
ceived 20l. 11s. as per account, S. L. Levine"—I did not see Beamond when I paid the money—nothing was said about the ownership of the goods—seventeen of the pieces were ultimately given to the policeman—the rest went into my stock, and have been sold.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long had you known Le
vine? A. About fifteen years—in the course of that time I have had many transactions with him as a commission-agent I never knew any thing likely to excite suspicion—I should not have dealt with him if I had—it is very common to sell in that way—some of the highest houses in London deal in that way, in cheap lots—I gave what I considered a fair price—I sold seven pieces at 4 1/4 d., and some at 4 1/2 d.—I should not have thought of giving 5d. for them—the goods were left with me some time, as I wished to be certain all was right—I did not know where Levine lived—I asked him to put his address on the invoices, and he put "No. 116, Lucas-street, Commercial-road," readily on my requesting him.

JOHN SAYWARD
re-examined. I buy my Scotch goods where I can get
them cheapest—I have some similar to what they brought, but not with the same stamp on them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What do you mean by similar? A. Goods got up in a similar way to these, of the same width—we buy them in 30
inch, 32
inch, and 34
inch.

JOHN SAYWARD . I am the last witness's father, and live in New Road, St. George's. In October I purchased two pieces of calico of Levine—I had this bill and receipt—I gave 4d. a yard—I said, "Make out a bill and receipt, I will pay you;" which he did—both the prisoners were together—(bill read)—"October 12, 1841. Mr. Sayward to S. L. Levine, 116, Lucas-street, Commercial-road, 2 pieces of calico, 120 yards and a half, at 4d., 2l. 0s. 2d. Received, S. L. LEVINE."—I delivered one of them to Miller, and the other my son had.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long have you been in business? A. Thirty years—I gave a fair price for these goods—I have known Levine some years, by being about the neighbourhood, and buying of him—he is a commission-agent—I saw nothing unfair in the transaction in any way—I got no profit on the piece I sold to my son.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When did your son have it? A. The next day—I did not want these goods particularly—they brought them in for a sample—I have bought goods with this mark on it, but it is two or three years ago—I bought them of a wholesale house.

— WILLIS (examined by MR. PHILLIPS,) I saw the person who came to take away the calico from Miller's Wharf, the man that came in a cart—only one man came after them—he was rather a tallish man, about five feet eight or nine inches—he was an elderly man, I should think about thirty-five—he was dressed in a dark frock
coat, I think a black coat—he came in the morning before with another man, whom I knew—his name was Richard Styles—Caywood was with me—I and he have not been talk
ing about it on the road—I was not told to describe the man who came for the calico.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was he either of the two prisoners? A. No.
GEORGE CAYWOOD (examined by MR. PHILLIPS.) I saw the man who came for the calico—I think he had a black coat on—I am quite sure it was neither of the prisoners.

HARRIET SLEGG . I am unmarried, and live at No. 116, Lucas-street, Commercial-road. I know Levine—he came to lodge at my house on the 9th of August—I have seen Beamond at my house—he came to see Le
vine—I might have seen him at the latter end of August, or the beginning of September—Beamond came to my house on the 13th of October—Levine was not at home—Beamond asked for him—he brought two par
cels of calico in a cart—one had the appearance of a bale, the other was in a bag—I told him Levine was not at home—he asked if he might leave the goods, and I gave him permission—he left two packages, a sort of bale and a bag—the bale was in paper—they were placed in my wash-house—I saw Levine about an hour afterwards, when he came to the door, and Beamond with him—Levine asked if there was any thing left for him—I said, "This gentleman has left two packages"—they went into the wash-house, and looked at the two parcels—I believe they took two pieces out of one of them at that time, and went out—the whole of the goods were taken away the next day, the Thursday, in a cab there were four pieces left behind, which I think must have come out of the bag—I do not think

the bale was opened at all—they took them away together—I am a dress-maker—there is no shop at my house—Levine asked me if I would like to purchase a piece—the four pieces were left in the wash-house before purchased one—I removed them from the wash-house, on account of the dampness, and put them in Levine's bed-room—I purchased one piece between myself and two friends—I gave 4 1/2 d. a yard for it—they came back together about five o'clock—they then took the three remaining pieces away—the bag was in the back parlour at the time they took that away with them.
Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. What business has Levine been carrying on? A. I considered him a commission-agent, and he sold goods for various persons—I know several he sold goods to.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When did Beamond first come to your place? A. About the latter end of August—I should think Levine had then been there a fortnight—Beamond brought a large quantity of lard with him —it was left at my house, and remained there four or five days—it came in a bag—it was taken away in smaller parcels—I saw no one take it but the two prisoners.

WILLIAM LAST . I am traveller to Luck and Co., of Bread-street, and live in Spencer-street, Goswell-road. They sell Gordon and Barren's Scotch goods—our cloth is stamped in red, but it is a particular stamp of our own—all our goods are delivered through Messrs. Sangster—I remember, six or weeks ago, calling on Mr. Sayward, junior—I saw there some pieces of calico like these that are here—they attracted my attention—I knew then as Gordon and Barron's factory—I went back to my employers, and told them I had seen them—I wrote a note to Sayward, and purchased the whole of them, twenty eight pieces, at 4 1/4 d. a yard—we sell them at 5d. and 5 1/2 d., and have a commission out of that—my attention was attracted by the lowness of the price in comparison with what we pay—a communi
cation was made to the house of Oliver, Dear, and Co., and to Sangster's—we have never sold so many as twenty-two pieces to any one person in town—one or two pieces of a width is the general quantity—they are sold at a list price.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. This is not the crest on your goods? A. No—ours is a lion—we are in the habit of sending these goods into the country—we have not had them above two months in the house—during that time 150 to 200 pieces have passed through our house.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. But you never sold any with the dove on them, or the stag like these? A. No.

HUGH RUSSELL . I am clerk in the house of George Sangster and Co., in Queen-street, Cheapside—they are agents to G. Forbes and Co.—there are two partners—I received, on the 15th of September, invoices for Oliver, Dear, and Co., Luck, and others, by post, that these things were to come—the bale marked "O. D. and Co.," was consigned to Sangster and Co., to be applied to the exclusive sale of Oliver, Dear, and Co.—those for Luck and the other, to whom they were directed—I have examined the whole of the pieces found—sixty-five "pieces—they are marked on the invoice "G. G. and P.," "O. D. and Co.," and bear the stamp peculiar to these marks—the goods are of the same description as those in the invoice in every respect—the bale marked "O. D. and Co." is No. 349, containing forty pieces thirty-two inches, hard finished—it corresponds in

all particulars with those which have been found—those marked "W. and G." correspond with those which have been found—they are hard finished—" G.G. and P." are called soft finished, and so are the goods—the width and the seal correspond exactly, and the general number that they pack is thirty in one bale, but "O. D. and Co." are packed forty; and of that mark here are thirty
three pieces found, which are three more than are usually supplied to any house but Oliver, Dear, and Co.—the signature, "John Russell, for George Sangster and Co.," on this order, is not my handwrit
ing—it is altogether a forgery—the marks in this order and the numbers correspond with the marks in the invoices which were duly remitted to us, so that the person who forged the order must have had access to that in
voice—inquiries were instituted by my principals into this matter, in con
sequence of information from Luck and Co., and on my going to the wharf I found this order—the printing is like our orders, but they have put the number of the premises 85, and our house is No. 5—(read)—" London, October 9, 1841. Mr. Hosie, Miller's Wharf, please to deliver R. Steynes the undermentioned goods, 21—40—84, 3 bales for G. Sangster and Co. H. RUSSELL."

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What number of these kind of goods are annually remitted from Scotland to your house? A. I cannot say—the dealings are very large—to the amount of some thousand pieces, and they are all marked as these are—they are sold to all the houses whose particular marks they bear, and sold at what they call a list price—they go into the country parts of England—I should say, under the cir
cumstances, that these goods have not travelled about—I will not say that some of them have not been in the country.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How do you know these? A. I have been round to the witnesses and found the goods to agree exactly with those missing, and I found from the persons I have been to that they could give me accounts of all they had been dealing with.

JAMES BROWN . I live at Aberdeen, and am in the employ of Alexander Forbes and others—they trade under the name of Gordon, Barron, and others. On the 27th of February, 1841, I packed three bales for Miller's-wharf, consigned to Sangster and Co.—I have got my book, in which I entered the goods as I packed them—one bale is entered in my own handwriting—they are marked with "O. D. and Co.," which I put on a bale forwarded for Oliver, Dear, and Co.—it was stamped with a dove in red—this piece corresponds with the quality, and finish, and the width, and the dove—about thirty pieces were marked with my own mark.

Q. Now look on the next occasion on which there was a package made up marked "G. G. P?" A. Yes—here it is—it is not in my own handwriting—I looked in the book and checked the packages as they were packed—about the 14th of September there were thirty pieces packed marked with a stag in red, the Aberdeen Arms, and Gordon, Barron, and Co.—this piece—(looking at one)—corresponds in all respects—this is soft-finished—the goods which were packed that day were soft-finished—about four of these are marked with my own handwriting—Mr. Forbes's name is Alexander, and there are several other partners.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many thousands of these are consigned from your house to London in the course of a year? About nine or ten thousand, on many of which I write figures—a great many of

them with these stags on them, and the Aberdeen Arms—there are thou
sands of pieces of soft-finish and of this width made up—I will not swear—I these came in the bales—they are similar—one piece is like another piece suppose twenty thousand have been marked with my figures in the last three years.

HUGH MCKENZIE . I am a bleacher in the employ of Gordon, Barron, and Co.—I have a book in which I enter the bleaching of their calico— this piece "O. D. and Co," with a stag on it, was bleached on the 18th of April, 1840—this piece, "No. 195," on the 1st of February, 1840—the whole of these marked "O. D. and Co." were bleached from September 14, 1839, to April 18—these marked "G. G. and P." were all bleached between the 1st of May, 1841, and the 22nd of the same month—on the 15th of September, 1841, I assisted in packing a bale for Miller's-Wharf, containing thirty pieces of thirty-two inch width and soft-finish, marked "G. G. and P."—these pieces which are here correspond in all particulars with the pieces I so packed—on the 1st of February, 1841, I assisted in packing a bale marked "W. G. and Co."—it contained thirty pieces of thirty inches wide, and hard-finish, what we call beetlings—some of the pieces here produced correspond in all particulars with them—no goods are sent to London with a dove on them, except to Oliver, Dear, and Co., nor any with a stag on them except to Grant, Grant, and Phillips.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many thousands of pieces are sent in the course of twelve months to these different houses? A. About ten thousand—these pieces which are here correspond in all respects with hundreds and thousands which are sent to London—I will not venture to say when these pieces came into this country.

WILLIAM NICOL (police-constable K 177.) I was called to the house of Mr. Speakman on the 15th of October—I found Levine there—he was given into custody—I told him he was charged on suspicion of stealing these goods, or being concerned with others in stealing them—he said, "I did not steal them, I was employed to sell them on commission"—I said, "For whom?"—he said "For a man name Beamond in Little St. Thomas Apostle"—he told me he did not exactly know the name of the man—after taking him to the station, in consequence of something he said to me, I went to a public-house in Whitecross-street, and took him with me—that was where he said the man would be found—we waited nearly an hour, and could find no man—I then went to Little St. Thomas Apostle and found Beamond there in the top back room in bed—there was only one bed and two or three chairs in the room—it was a very small room—Levine went in with me—he said to Beamond, "They have taken me about the calico"—Beamond said, "You did not sell it for me"—Levine said, "But I sold it with you"—Beamond then got up and I took him away—Levine told me previously that he had sold some to Mr. Manning—I went there and received seventeen pieces of calico—Levine said he would tell all when he got before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Levine was giving you an account of the pieces he had sold? A. Yes—he said he had sold twenty or twenty-four pieces to Mr. Manning—he told me voluntarily about Mr. Manning.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you give the pieces of goods you received to Miller? A. I did.
ELIAS MILLER (City police-constable No. 408.) I have produced sixty-five
pieces of calico—I received twenty-eight of them at the house of Luck and Co., seven from Sayward the younger, one from the father, twelve from Speakman, and seventeen from Manning.

GEORGE GILBERT . I am in the employ of Oliver, Dear, and Co. Mr. Dear's name is James—Mr. Oliver is deceased—there are others—they are consignees of all the calico that comes from the house of Gordon, Barron, and Co., marked with the dove—it is not a common occurrence to sell as many as thirty pieces to one purchaser.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you speak from your own recollection or from books? A. From both—I have referred to the books to be perfectly certain—I could trust to my memory, but this was so sin
gular a circumstance that I referred to the books.

MR. BODKIN. Q. For the last four years have you sold forty pieces to one person? A. Yes. on the 12th of December, 1840, to Mr. Amos, of Bristol—that is the only instance in which forty pieces have been sold to one customer these four years.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many pieces do you dispose of in the course of a year with the dove on? A. I do not know—I will not swear that we have not distributed twenty thousand through England in the last three years—we are the only persons who receive those with the dove on them, and we distribute them—there are but few sold in London—I should think not thirty pieces in a year.

JOHN BRAND (City police-constable, No. 316.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Beamond's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the man who was then tried and convicted.

(Benjamin Dudfield, a custom-house broker; Moses Cohen, a merchant;—Emanuel, watch
maker, of the Minories;—Poland, a tailor; and Morris Simmonds, of Prescott-street; gave Levine a good character.)

LEVINE—
GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

BEAMOND—
GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Twenty Years.

226.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of No
vember, 1 coat, value 15s., the goods of
George Thomas Beare.

GEORGE THOMAS BEARE . I am a seaman, and lodge at Mr. M'Carthy's. I pulled off my coat and left it on the kitchen table on the 23rd of No
vember—Mr. M'Carthy came and asked if this was my coat, and it is.

ISABELLA M'CARTHY . I live with my brother John, who keeps a lodg
ing-house for seamen. On the 23rd of November I saw the prisoner, who had no business in the house—he had no coat on—he went into the kitchen and put this coat on in my presence—he went up stairs with it—I told my brother, who stopped him in the passage with it.
WILLIAM ISAAC (police-constable K 223.) I took the prisoner—he denied being near the house—he said he had been out and sold his mats—he had got as far as Welclose-square.

Prisoner. I was along with a man-of-war's man—he said, "Where is the house?"—I showed him the house—he said, "There is a coat down stairs, go and put it on"—I went down and took it—a drunken sailor went down with me.

ISABELLA M'CARTHY
re-examined. A man came in with him who he lodged there, but was not drunk.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

227.
JAMES GIRDLESTONE was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of November, 1 box, value 6d.; 1 coat, value 7s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 2s.; 2 pairs of breeches, value 4s.; 3 shirts, value 3s.; 3 cravats, value 1s.; 2 shirt
fronts, value 1s.; 3 stockings, value 6d.; 3 handker
chiefs, value 6d.; 1 printed book, value 6d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1d.,; and 1 pack of cards, value 4d.; the goods of
John Coker.

JOHN COKER . I am a private in the 16th regiment of Lancers. I left a box at No. 25, Dean-street, Westminster—it contained the coat and other articles stated—this now produced is my box and the property in it.

JOHN MOORE . I live at No. 25, Dean-street. On the 18th of Novem
ber, about half-past ten o'clock in the forenoon, the prisoner came and said that John Coker had sent him for the box—I gave it him and its contents.
JOHN COKER . I did not send him for the box—I had known him for about ten days.

JAMES CLIFT (police-constable A 121.) I found the box in Castle-street, Long-acre—it was not locked—the prisoner said at the station that he had not been sent for it—he said it was at Castle-street, Long-acre.
Prisoners Defence. A young man told me to go for it; I gave it to him, and he was taken in Charles-street, Long-acre.

JAMES CLIFT
re-examined. The other man was taken, but released.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Four Months.

228.
THOMAS REDDINGTON and
MICHAEL JENNINGS were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November, 1 chair, value 8d., the goods of
John Hargrave; and that they had been before convicted of felony; and
CHARLES UNDERWOOD
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM VICTORY . I live with my father, in New-street, Westminster, I was in Husband-street, St. James's, and saw Reddington take a chair that belonged to Mr. Hargrave—he gave the chair to Jennings, who carried it across the road to No. 2, Hopkins-street—Reddington went up Hopkins-street, and went away—it was between seven and eight o'clock in the evening.

ELEANOR HARGRAVE . I am the wife of John Hargrave. I missed a chair like this on that day, but I have not sworn to this, it is so very frivo
lous—I do not wish to be hard on the boys.

JOHN WILLS (police-constable C 125.) I went to Underwood's, in Hopkins-street—he has an apartment there—I asked him where he got this chair from—he said some of the boys had brought it—he did not know what boys—I found it near ten o'clock in the evening.

Reddington's Defence. I was not out after five o'clock that evening, which my aunt can prove. The officer took me as I was going to bed, at half-past eleven, in my aunt's room. Victory is a thief. I was going down the Haymarket one night, and he asked me to pawn a handker
chief for him. I got 2s. on it. I did not see him that night, and I wanted something to eat; I spent a shilling, and the next morning I told him I had spent the money—I gave him the ticket.
Jennings Defence. I was not in the parish that night till ten o'clock.
GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I produce a certificate of Jenning's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.
JOSEPH MOUNT (police-constable C 115.) I produce a certificate of Reddington's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

REDDINGTON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

JENNINGS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years.

UNDERWOOD—
NOT GUILTY .

229.
CHARLES UNDERWOOD was again indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 22nd of November, of an evil
disposed person, 1 chair, value 9d., the goods of
Anderson Campbell, well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
MARY CAMPBELL . I am the wife of Anderson Campbell; he lives in New-street, Seven Dials. On the evening of the 22nd of November I lost a chair—this is it.

THOMAS WELLS (police-sergeant C 1.) I found this chair at the pri
soner's the second evening after it was lost.
NOT GUILTY .

230.
CHARLES DARBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of November, 1 cloak, value 15s., the goods of
Gregory Dumanski.
GREGORY DUMANSKI . I was at the Palace Arms public-house, Pimlico, on the evening of the 30th of November, and lost my cloak—this now produced is it.

JOHN PENROSE . I was at the Palace Arms, on the evening of the 30th, of November, about half-past nine o'clock—I saw the prosecutor and pri
soner there.

JOHN CURRY . I am a corporal in the First Battalion of Coldstream Guards. I met the prisoner at a quarter-past ten o'clock that night—he had a bundle with him which contained the cloak—I took him into custody.
Prisoners Defence. I went into the Horse Guards and had a pint of beer; a gentleman asked me to drink with him, which I did; I then went out, and a man gave me the cloak to pawn.

GUILTY .* Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

231.
WILLIAM CAPES was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of November, 13lbs. weight of bacon, value 7s., the goods of
John Ayling; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN AYLING . I live in Barnard-street, Bethnal-green; I keep a shop.—On the evening of the 25th of November, I was sitting in my par
lour, and heard somebody come into the shop—I looked, and missed two pieces of bacon—I went out and found the prisoner, who had one of them under his arm—I had seen them safe three or four minutes before.
WILLIAM THOMPSON . I saw the prisoner take the bacon from another person, who came out of the shop with two pieces—he was three or four yards from the shop.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to buy it; he left one piece with me, and ran off.

GEORGE TREW . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.

232.
JOHN ROSS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of July, 3 shirts, value 9s.; and 1 towel, value 6d.; the goods of
Martha Dixon.

The property belonging to Mary Dixon, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

233.
ELIZABETH M'CABE was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of July, 1 spoon, value 2s.; 1 pair of stays, value 4s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 1 napkin, value 6d.; 1 pair of ear
rings and drops, value 7s. 3 necklaces, value 12s.; 1 brooch, value 6s.; 11 knives, value 4s.; 10 forks, value 2s.; 2 salt-cellars, value 1s.; 1 wine-glass, value 8d.; 1 rummer, value 1s.; 1 tumbler glass, value 1s.; 2 mugs, value 9d.; 9 chimney-ornaments, value 1s.; 2 soap-trays and covers, value 1s.; 5 brushes, value 18d.; 3 cakes of soap, value 6d.; and 2 ba
sins, value 3d.; the goods of
James Beagley, her master.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES BEAGLEY . I keep the Camden Head public-house, Camden-town. The prisoner has been in my service from six to ten months, and in consequence of something which happened, I asked her if she had seen any body go up stairs—I asked her for the key of her box—she said she would not give it me—I asked if she would allow her box to be searched—she said no, nobody should search it; there was nothing there which it was not fit for a man to see—I asked her to allow my wife to search it—she said no—I said, "If you have any thing belonging to me, give it up"—her mother lived at Ratcliff, five or six miles from me—I gave her into custody—she would not go up to have her box searched—sergeant Daniels was present when a witness searched it—it was not opened till he was present, and the door of the room was locked.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. She had been nine or ten months in your service? A. From six to ten—we had the greatest respect for her, every body in the house had—she was a good servant, but I thought she had some bad adviser—I would have permitted her to be bar-maid, if she Would have liked to take it—I was talking about it, but my mistress said, "Stop a little till we get busier"—my mistress did not object to it, she was so fond of my little boy—she is between nineteen and twenty years old—she had perquisites in her situation—they were not a great deal, perhaps 2s. 6d.—a-week, sometimes 4s. or 5s.—it is a small public-house—she was house
maid, and waited in the parlour—I had no barmaid at the time, only my wife, my mother-in-law, and sister—my mother-in-law was going to leave.
Q. Does Mrs. Beagley occasionally take a little drink? A. Never—I know what occurred yesterday—I blowed her up yesterday for going into a hot room where there was smoking going on.

Q. Was she so drunk yesterday that she could not cross the road with
out your assistance? A. No; fainting—I never knew her drunk—I never offered the prisoner two sovereigns—there have been jokes between us, and before my wife—when she was nursing my boy, going to take him out a walk, the boy has said, "Dada, kiss me before I go; now kiss Lilabella

I do not call her by that name—her name is Elizabeth—at the office she booked her name as "Betsy"—that is what I call her—I do not deny but I have made her one of the family, and she had a good situation—I certainly have kissed her when the boy has asked me—the boy is only two years old—I went to the prisoner's father while she was locked up—I did not tell him that as soon as she got out of this I would take her back again—I swear that—never any thing of the sort—I did not tell him I had been kissing her—there never was any unpleasant feeling at home about this—the pri
soner never complained of my conduct to her—she always behaved as a good girl till this happened—I never endeavoured to thrust my hand up her petticoats—what I have done I am not ashamed to do before any body, I have done nothing to the girl though I am accused of it, and my character injured—it is merely the town talk since she has been in custody—I never heard it before.

Q. Did you ever ask her for a lock of her hair? A. Never, no more than a lock of my wife's hair given me before I was married, was set in a brooch—it came home from being repaired—I asked Betsy to look at it—she said, "Dear me, it looks a great deal better than it did, is that your mistress's hair?"—I said, "Yes, Betsy, you have got a good looking head of hair; if I was a young man, not married, I should like a lock of it in a brooch"—she turned round, and said, "Master, I should not like to give my hair away without it was to somebody I respected"—I said, "Oh, Betsy, I am a married man."

Q. Did she call out, and tell your wife of it? A. Oh no, it was merely a joke—she never gave notice to leave—I never heard that she had done so—I never heard it was said so—she did not bring a sovereign to me which she had found—it was laying on the table about half-past seven one morning, I was serving customers—my wife was in bed—we take it by turns to get up in the morning—my man and me are always up first—I did not know the sovereign was there—she did not bring it to me—she said, "Master, here's a sovereign"—I said, "Oh, I suppose my wife left it there last night?"—I have a tailors' club held there, and I suppose she gave change late at night—this was about three or four, two months ago.

Q. Did you ever tell her not to go to the house of your wife's mother? A. She would not allow her to come—I told her she was not allowed to go—I never told her not to go—I had quarrelled with my mother-in-law—my mistress said to my mother-in-law, who went to live opposite us, "I will send Elizabeth over for the boy," and my mother-in-law said, "If Elizabeth comes, I will slap the door in her face"—I told her my mo
ther-in-law would not allow her to come over to fetch the boy, and would slap the door in her face—I did not tell her they were jealous of her—it was about three weeks or a month ago that I talked to her about being bar-maid—I gave her into custody yesterday fortnight.

Q. Did she refuse to take the bar-maid's place? A. I did not put the question to her—all I said, was, "I must have a bar-maid," and said to my wife, "We may as well learn Elizabeth the business, and have some
body to do her work"—I said to her, "If you like to take this place, I shall advance your wages"—she did not refuse it—she said she should not dislike it.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you any idea that she was robbing you at that time? A. None at all.

RICHARD DANIEL (police-sergeant S 12.) I was called in by Mr. Beagley on the 23rd of November—I went and saw the prisoner—I was present when her boxes were opened—one I opened with a key which I found in her pocket—the other was opened by a locksmith—I asked her to give me the pocket, and in the pocket I found the key of the first box—she gave me some keys on a ring—I found a key for the other box, but I could not open it with the key—it would not open it—I found in her boxes some knives and forks, a quantity of farthings, some crockery, linen, a pair of stays, some china ornaments, and some carpet—I said nothing to her about them—she was in custody, and not present.

Cross-examined. Q. How many boxes were there? A. Two—they were in a back room at the top of the house—I believe this key opened the box—I rather think this is the key which belonged to the other box which I could not open readily—I did not take the lock off—I thought the key was too small for the lock—I did not notice whether the aperture for the lock appeared the shape of the key—I did not find that the lock had been hampered—I will not swear it had not—I tried it and found I could not open it, and the locksmith said he thought it was on account of the lock having been a little rusty, not that it was not the key, but that the lock was rusty—that was his opinion—I have a list here of what I found in each box—in the box which opened easily, I found six plates, two salt-glasses, two basins, one wine-glass, one rummer, one tumbler, and two china cups—I beg to say that this is to the best of my belief—the room is very small, and there was a bad light—there was also one jug, two bottles of oil, three cakes of soap, one housewife, nine chimney-ornaments, one candlestick, one pair of snuffers, one corkscrew, four brushes, two pieces of carpet, and a piece of green baize—the knives were found in the box the key would not open—the articles named at the top of this list were found in the second box, I think as far as the knives—all the articles were found in the two boxes—I found the money and bag in the second box—the hampered one.

ISAAC SAMUEL BOWLINE . I am a locksmith and bell-hanger. I went to the Camden Head public-house, to open a box—I picked the lock in the usual way, because the key would not open the shoot—the police-ser
geant was with me.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you taken the trouble to take off the lock? A. No—I am not employed to do it,—(box produced) I rather think this key belongs to the box I picked, or this—the lock appeared to want oiling, and I found in a hole where the staple went down, a piece of straw bent, or something had got in, the lock had not got its action—the lock seemed corroded.

Q. How long would it take corroding? A. It depends on the situa
tion it is in—it might become dusty or damp—it might be so in three months, or it might be twelve months—the lock catches—the shoot will not go back—it is not the wards that are affected—it is the bolt.

MARY BEAGLEY . I believe the two boxes which have been produced, to be the prisoners—they were in the room she slept in—they are not mine—I have looked at the articles produced, and know them to be my own property, every thing here is mine—the knives and forks are mine—I know this carpet—it was taken off the parlour benches by the carpenter, and was found in the prisoner's box—it was taken off the benches because it was worn out—we were going to have the benches re-carpeted—I know
these plates and ornaments—this soap-dish and crockery for a dressing-table are mine—these basins, and the brushes are mine—the brushes are new, and have never been used.
Cross-examined. Q. I am afraid you are not very well, or is there any thing the matter with you? A. I am very well, thank you—I was very middling indeed yesterday.

Q. Very middling, I believe, when you were in the middle of the road? A. I was not very well—I had been to the public-house a short time before—I do not know the sign of the house—I cannot say what time I got there yesterday morning—I had nothing to drink there—I will swear that—I had not any thing to drink at the public-house—I did not bring any drink with me—I do not say I had nothing to drink all day—I had some porter at the public-house—nothing else—I swear that—I had nothing to drink any where else—I was very well when I had drunk the porter—I cannot say to a few moments how soon after I became middling—I am occasionally in the habit of taking a little something when I am at home—I consider every body requires a little refreshment—I take a little spirits occasionally—not in the morning, unless I am very unwell—some
times I may be very well of a morning, and sometimes unwell—when unwell of a morning I have taken a little spirits—I have quarrelled with my mother occasionally, not very often—she has left our house—the prisoner never gave me notice to quit nor notice to leave at all—she never gave me any warning whatever to leave the house—I never knew that my husband was in the habit of kissing her—he never kissed her in my presence—I should certainly have been very angry if he had—these jokes have not taken place in my presence.

Q. Do you remember your husband wanting her to be bar-maid? A. He spoke of it—I said it should not be—I would not have it on any account—I did not think we required a bar-maid—I believe my mother has said she should never like the girl to come into her house—as she was very disagreeable to my mother—I did not like her much, because she made herself unpleasant to the family—I do not say she was unkind to the little boy—she behaved as a servant ought to the child—I never noticed any particular fondness to the child—the prisoner was sometimes called Elizabeth, and sometimes Betsy—no other name by me, nor in my presence or hearing—the little boy never said, in my presence, "Papa, kiss me, and now kiss' Lillabella' "—I should certainly have been very angry if it had.

Q. Do you remember ever hearing of a lock of hair that was put into a brooch? A. I have heard speak of it—I cannot positively say who I have heard speak of it—I have heard it pass as a joke—I cannot say how long it was before the prisoner was taken up—I should think it was a week be
fore—it was before she was taken up—I cannot tell who talked about it—my husband was there.
COURT. Q. Whose hair was put into the brooch? A. It was supposed to be hers.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You supposed so, did you not? A. It was sup
posed to be hers—I did not suppose so—they were talking about a brooch—I supposed it to be my own, because I had given my husband such a one before I was married—I do not believe it to be her hair—I believed it to be hers then, and said so.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How much did you drink of the porter yesterday?

A. I might have drunk half a pint, or a little better—there is no pretence that I am aware of for saying that I was intoxicated—there was smoking in the room—I drank nothing before I left home—no spirits—I had taken breakfast—I did not take porter, or any thing at breakfast.
Q. What do you attribute your feeling faint or middling to? A. I had not been well for some time.

COURT. Q. Have you been worried about the prisoner? A. I have very much—I did not exactly think my husband too free with her—I have heard him joke with her—I did not consider there was any thing improper between them—I certainly was uneasy about her when I could not meet my demands—I knew nobody but her and my own family went to my bed-room—I was not uneasy about my husband being attentive to her—we have cupboards to put the old carpet and things away in—I dare say this carpet would have been joined together, and used for the servant's-room, or some purpose—I did not give any directions what was to be done with it—I mean to represent on my oath that I was not intoxicated yester
day.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Will you swear you were not intoxicated at Marylebone office when you were there? A. I can swear it.

GEORGE GEORGE . I am a table-knife cutler. These knives and forks produced are what I sold to Mr. Beagley some time in May last—I sold him some on several occasions—I recognize these as having been sold to him.

JURY. Q. What makes you recollect the knives as being sold in May to Mr. Beagley? A. It so happened that the blades of part of them are what I took out of some old silver handles—being a working man I know them.
JOHN HADGLEY . I am a carpenter. I know this capet—I took a carpet of his description off the seats at the Camden Head, public-house—I have a piece in my pocket to match it—I put new carpet on.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you get that piece from, Mr. Beagley? A. No—it was in my basket, which had been standing there—I took it off the seats in August.
COURT. Q. How came you to have part of it in your basket? A. By standing against the back door—I cut it off another piece that was there—they asked me if I could bring a piece like it.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have brought a piece of carpet there, what do you consider it matches with? A. I cannot see any match of the pattern or width—it is not the same pattern.

COURT. Q. Where did you get it, and how came you to bring it here? A. It was lying against Mr. Beagley's back-door, along the landing—I cut it off myself—Mr. Beagley asked me if I could bring a piece—I cut it off another piece, which came off the seat—I took it off myself before I put the other on.
(The carpet produced was a very different pattern to that the witness had.)

MARY BEAGLEY
re-examined. This is my signature to this deposition—it was read over to me before I signed it.

Q. Read the last two lines of it? A. (reads)—"The stays are mine, and have been stolen from my drawers, so have the napkins, ear-rings, and jetkins."—I adhere to that statement—I swear the stays are mine, and were stolen from my drawers, with the napkins, ear-rings, and jetkins.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

JUST RANGER . I am a draper, and live in Well's-row, Islington. I know this pair of stays perfectly well—I sold them to the prisoner, I think about eighteen months ago, or it may be something less—I cannot speak exactly to the date—I know them by the characters in the busk in the centre being in my own handwriting, which I put on myself—the letters "1 g," which is the private mark for 5s. 6d—I have been in business myself about six months, but at the time these stays were sold I carried on the same business for Mr.—of Islington.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do they seem to have been worn? A.—Yes, they certainly have—I cannot say whether any one was present when I sold them—I think not—I remember the circumstance perfectly well, from having sold a pair to the prisoner the evening before, which, being a misfit, she exchanged—there are two "1 g's" on them—the top characters look like mine, but the second I can swear to—I am not in the habit of making a double set of characters—my employer, at the time I first lived with him, occupied the house in Wells-row, and while with him he took premises in High-street—the greater part of the stock was transferred to the pre
mises he now occupies—having the order from the prisoner for a pair of stays, I sent down to him to state the same, and these were the pair sent up—they might have had the characters on in pencil when they were at the other shop—I cannot say that I remember the double set of characters being on them—according to my impression I put both, but the second I put when I received the stays from the other house—both marks are in pencil.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you go before the Magistrate and make this statement? A.—Yes.

WILLIAM BLACKMAN . I keep a glass and broker's shop, at No. 6, York-street, Camden-town. This pair of salt-cellars I sold—I have had them frequently in my hand—I had them by me some time, and people ex-amined them almost every day.

Q. To whom did you sell them? A. I should not like to swear posi
tively to the prisoner, but I really believe it to be her—I think it must be near upon three months ago—I am sure I sold them to a young woman—I am sure they are the same—I went before the Magistrate to state this.

CAROLINE BETTELEY . I am the wife of Jacob Betteley, a china and glass dealer, and live at No. 128, High-street, Camden-town. We keep a shop—I know the prisoner—I sold her such a soap-dish and brush-tray as these—I cannot say bow long ago, but it may be about six months ago—I have such articles in my shop now—I believe these to be the articles I sold her.

MRS. BEAGLEY re-examined. I believe this to be the brooch I spoke to before the Magistrate—I believe it to be ours—I was present when these things were found in the boxes—they all belong to the house—I believe the brooch to be ours—it resembles it, and I believe it is ours.

JAMES SERGEANT. I live at No. 125, High-street, Camden-town. I believe this to be the brooch I sold to the prisoner about six or eight weeks ago—I am positive I sold her one of that pattern, and I believe this to be it.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you any entry in your book about it? A. No, we do not make entries—I am a hair-dresser, and sell brooches and fancy articles—I do a good business—we keep books, but do not enter

articles we sell, except on credit—we do not enter in a cash-book—I am not the proprietor of the shop—I do not know whether my employer keeps a cash-book or not—I never saw one—if there was one, it would be my duty to enter what was sold in it—I have no private mark on the brooch.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. That is the reason you do not speak positively? A. Yes—we always put the private mark on a ticket, which we take off when we sell it—the price of it is 4s. 6d.—or 5s.—it is mosaic gold—my master keeps a shop.
COURT. Q. When you sell an article at 4s., do not you state to your master, "I have sold this at 4s.,?" A. My employer happened to be in the shop at the time the prisoner bought it.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you quite sure this is the girl? A. Positive—I have lived with my master eight years.
J—HUNTSMAN. I am a chemist and druggist, and live at No. 47, High-street, Camden-town. I sold the prisoner a scent-bottle with a silver top, with a ring at the back—it was puce or purple glass.

RICHARD DANIELS
re-examined. I had one answering that description, but I believe it is not included in this charge—it was property supposed to belong to the prisoner, and not produced before the Magistrate.

NICHOLAS M'CABE . I am a coal and coke dealer, and live at No. 3, Bear-street, Ratcliff. The prisoner is my daughter—she was eight years in good service before she went to Mr. Beagley's—I believe she had 15l. in her possession before she went there; I often told her to put it in the Savings'-bank, but she has said, "Oh, father, it is safe enough in my box"—I have seen the prosecutor since my daughter has been in custody—he came to the house I was at, not my house—he told me, on that occasion, that if my daughter got out of this scrape, he would take her again into his service; he said he would take her to
morrow if her trial was over to-day.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there any one present when he said that? A. Yes, my wife and the woman who owned the house—I do not know her name—she is not here—I was overcome at the Court-house, and was forced to be carried out into a house; they gave me a drink of water, I recovered myself, and sat on a chair about an hour; and during that time Mr. Beagley came in to me, and said, "When the trial is over, I shall take her to
morrow"—this was a little while before the trial came on, the day she had her first hearing at Marylebone—I cannot tell what time of the day it was—it was in the afternoon—I cannot tell what o'clock—it was in one of the little houses that join the police-office—a private house—I was overcome at seeing her at the office, and was taken there—she never put the 15l. into any savings'-bank, or she would have told me so—I am certain of it—I often told her to do it, and she said her money was safe enough in her box—she told me so two or three months before she was taken up, or more than three months—I know she did not put it into the savings'-bank.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did she ever tell you any thing about being the barmaid? A. She did—she gave me a reason for declining to be barmaid—that reason applied to Mrs. Beagley.

ANN M'CABE . I am the prisoner's step-mother. I remember her en
tering Mr. Beagley's service—she had 15l., then—it was in gold—I saw it when she was packing her clothes in her box—she had a coral necklace,

and an imitation pearl necklace—I remember her coming home while in Mr. Beagley's service, about two months before she was taken up—she made a complaint about her box having been attempted—she had some far
things from me when she left our house—I cannot tell the number—I told her to take what quantity she liked out of the drawer—I always have a number of farthings—my husband wants them in his business—I know she had black-drop earrings, and she lost the top of one—she also had a black necklace, and I wore it on my own neck on going to a funeral—to the best of my belief this is the necklace, and these the drop earrings—I have been her step
mother eleven years, and never knew her deprive a single person of a farthing.

WILLIAM HENRY FINCH . I live at No. 5, Moon-street, Islington. I was sent to pay some money for a coral necklace for the prisoner—it was such a necklace as this—I brought it home for her—I have known her about two years—I never heard any thing against her character till she was apprehended—I knew her living at the Angel and Crown, Islington, for twelve months.

MARY LAINSON . I live at No. 27, Aldgate. These black earrings and necklace are similar articles to what I sell—I cannot positively say I sold them—I never sold the prisoner a pair of black earrings like these, to my recollection—I have no recollection of it whatever—it is impossible for me to say whether I sold such articles on the 19th of August—I do not enter articles in a book—I sell similar earrings to these—I see this is my box they are in, and that is quite sufficient, for this box was given with the articles—I am in the habit of placing articles in a box in this way—that is my box, but that does not imply that they are my earrings.

COURT to MRS. BEAGLEY. Q. Can you state where you got these jet ornaments? A. I bought them in Tottenham-court-road, to the best of my belief—I cannot tell the person's name—it is some years back—I bought the brooch just on the other side of the New-road, at Mr. Baylis's, I believe, some years back—I never wore it above once—I dare say per
sons have seen me wear it—I generally kept my earrings in a box in cotton—I bought this pair of earrings, I think, of a Mr. Harrison—I have worn them—it is more than two years ago since I wore them—they were perfect top was not off—I believe I gave 4s. 6d. for them—I cannot say—one what I gave for the brooch—I bought the stays at the bar, over the counter of the public-house—I cannot positively say who of—I did not try them on to see if they would fit—the general way of trying is by a piece of tape—I cannot positively say when I bought them—it was of a woman—I cannot say in what year, or whether it is five years ago.

Q. On the solemn oath you have taken, do you mean to represent you bought these stays over the bar; take warning before you answer? A. It might be in the kitchen—I will swear I bought them either in the bar or kitchen—I cannot say when—I frequently buy things of people in the kitchen—when people stand at the bar, we ask them to come into the kitchen.

Q. Is there any human being who ever saw you in possession of the stays? A. I do not know—on my oath the stays belong to me—I do not know what letters are on them—I tried them on, but not to wear them any length of time—I never wore them—they did not fit then—I have not tried them on since the prisoner has been apprehended—I do not think I tried them on this year—I rather think it was last year.
JULIA SULLIVAN . I am a widow. I was outside in the neighbourhood

of this Court yesterday, between three and four o'clock, and saw Mrs. Beagley tipsy in the court-yard, and in the public-house—her husband as
sisted her across the road—she was drunk.
COURT. Q. Can you be mistaken, could it be faintness or any other cause? A. No, she was laughed at by the men.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there any body with her but her husband? A. No, it was not faintness—I could not be mistaken, it was too evident—she stood up in the court-yard, against the railings, to recover herself—she could not stand—I saw her drink brandy twice, as well as porter, yes
terday, at the public-house.

FRANCIS JOHN HOLLOWAY . I am a sail-maker. I came to the Old Bailey yesterday with a friend, to see a person named Evans, a stranger, who had come up about a situation—I met with him in the Old Bailey—I saw Mrs. Beagley cross the road from the Pitt's Head public-house over to this Court—she appeared to me in a beastly state of intoxication—she fell down on one knee, and was pulled up again by the man with her—I believe she was intoxicated.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you in the public-house? A. I had been in it, but was coming away—I was not in it while she was there—I am not acquainted with the prisoner's father—I saw him here this morning—I have spoken to him—I spoke to him four or five days ago for the first time in my life—it is since the sessions have been on—I heard from a friend of mine that he had a daughter here—I was along with Mr. Silvester—the father told me about his daughter's case.

COURT. Q. Do you take an interest in it from what he said? A. I took an interest so far as this, I came with Mr. Silvester, who took an ac
tive part in the prisoner's defence.
NOT GUILTY .

233.
ELIZABETH M'CABE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of November, in the dwelling-house of
James Beagley, 1 piece of printed-paper, value 1/2 d.; 13 sovereigns, and 5 half-sovereigns, and other monies, his property.

JAMES BEAGLEY . While the prisoner was in my service I missed some money—in consequence of that, and what happened in the last case, I had the policeman called in and the prisoner's box examined—I first had my man's box searched—the policeman examined the prisoner's box and found the money in question, which is the subject of this indictment—I had a forged 1l. note, and that was found in the prisoner's box among other things.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. You were in Court when your wife was examined? A. Yes.

Q. Did you hear her swear that you never joked or took any liberty with the prisoner in her presence? A. She said not to my notice—I have kissed the girl in her presence once or twice—not often—I cannot say how often—I will swear it was not a dozen times—we made the girl one of our family—perhaps I may have kissed her a dozen times.

COURT. Q. Did you not before her box was opened, tell her that if she would deliver up the things or the money, you would let her go quietly away unharmed? A. I did—she said she had nothing in her box that did not belong to her—but she would not allow a man to overhaul her things—I proposed that my wife should do it, and she declined, saying she

wished the box opened in the presence of her mother—I first sent her away in custody, and then let the policeman examine her boxes—she re
fused to go up stairs, and insisted on her mother being sent for before they were examined.

Q. On your solemn oath, was not your wife drinking brandy at the public-house yesterday? A. In the public-house after standing some time, I believe I got her some—she tasted it—I found her sitting there by her
self—I said, "It is very foolish to sit here among the smoke, you will get overcome"—I blowed her up for being in a smoky-room—she had got damp in her feet.

Q. When had you seen the forged note? A. I do not know that I had seen it for twelve months, but I cannot say how long—I do not think it is two years—it belongs to my wife—her mother had taken it—she is not here.

COURT. Q. Where was your money kept? A. In the left-hand corner of a drawer in my bed-room—the drawer was not locked—the money had not been there long—I suppose about six or seven weeks—sometimes the door was locked, and sometimes not—there was no key of the drawer—I had a sister of my wife's in the establishment—she is not here—she re
sorted to the room, and my wife, myself, and the servant.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you mean to swear the girl did not on two occasions give you notice to leave, and at last say she would quit on the 7th of the month, when her quarter was up? A. Never—I never offered her two sovereigns.

COURT. Q. How do you know what money you had? A. I cannot say within a few pounds, between 40l. and 50l. I do not know the 10l. note, or the three 5l. notes—they have not been found—no note has been found but the forged note—I had talked about the forged note, it had "forged" stamped right across it—the prisoner can read.
JURY. Q. Did you ever pay the prisoner any money? A. Not one farthing. not for wages—I dare say my wife has advanced her some.
MRS. BEAGLEY. I never paid any wages to the prisoner—I never gave her any money.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear you never paid her any money during the six or ten months she lived with you? A. Let me recollect myself if you please—I believe I did, I think it was about 5l.
COURT. Q. Where did you keep your keys? A. Generally down stairs in the bar—I very seldom take them out—I have not got them with me now—I cannot exactly say how the forged note got into the box.

RICHARD DANIEL . I am a policeman. This forged note was found in the box, the lock of which was hampered—all the money was found in that box—I saw no keys besides those the prisoner gave up—I did not apply to any one for keys before I broke open the box—I had no conversation with Mrs. Beagley before the box was broken open—Mr. Beagley sug
gested that it should be broken open—the first box I went to was the one which opened readily—that box was not full—I cannot tell which box the carpet was in—I heard the prisoner refuse to have her box opened in the presence of any man, and I did not think it any use to ask her to see it opened, although nothing had been found against her when she was given
in charge—it did not occur to me—I heard her entreat that her mother should be sent for before any box was opened.
NOT GUILTY .

234.
GEORGE HYAMS was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 1st of November, of an evil-disposed person, 27 yards of satin, value 6l.; and 9 yards of silk quiltings, value 4l. 10s.; the goods of
James Dickons Saltmer, well knowing them to have been stolen.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

MOSES CORONEL . I am shopman to Mr. George Wood who keeps a clothes shop in Holywell-street. On the 18th of November, the witness, M'Knight, came to my master's shop—in consequence of what took place between us, I went to Mr. Saltmer, in Friday-street, and made a communi
cation there of what had happened.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe M'Knight told you all manner of falsehoods? A. He did, innumerable falsehoods—I should not think his word was to be taken on any occasion—he denied most decidedly before my face every thing that had taken place between us—he told me he came from Bread-street, which was quite false—he gave me the slip in a very cunning wry—he went into a shop, told me to wait for him, and he got out at the back-door—in consequence of my suspicion, I took a cab, and went to Mr. Saltmer to put him on his guard—M'Knight wanted me to buy some articles—he said they were taking stock at his firm, and when there were short lengths, they were divided among the young men in the establishment—he nearly deceived me altogether—when I saw him at Mr. Saltmer's, I asked why he kept me so long in St. Martins-lane—he said, "Who are you, and what are you?"—I said, "I think you have made nice sort of fun of me, deceiving me in this way," and I called him a confounded thief—he said, "If you call me a thief, I will make you prove your words," and denied having seen me at all.

MR. BODKIN. Q. What articles did he bring to you to sell? A. Silk velvet waistcoat-pieces—these now produced are them—I should think they are worth about 6l.—they might cost more to be cut off a piece, but as remnants they are worth about that—I asked what he wanted for them—he said, "I think they are worth 1l."—my suspicions were then aroused—there are six lengths, and I should think them worth 1l. each.

BENJAMIN M'KNIGHT . I am sixteen years old. In October last I was in the employ of Mr. Saltmer—I have been with him little more than three months—my father is also in his service, and has been so for about two years. On the 18th of November I went to Mr. Coronel's, No. 1, Holywell-street—about a week before that I had been to No. 17, which is the prisoner's—my attention was first attracted there by seeing a board outside, stating that they bought goods—I had nothing with me when I first noticed that board—I spoke to the prisoner on that occasion—he was at the door—I asked him if he would buy some figured satins—he said, "Yes"—I went there next evening with four pieces of black quiltings, and three lengths of figured satin, about nine yards in, each length—these are the black quilt
ings I took—(looking at four pieces)——took the satins and quiltings from my master's stock—I have since pointed out to my master the patterns in the warehouse of the silks I so took—I wrapped them up in a brown paper

parcel—I got to the prisoner's house about half-past five o'clock—he was at the door—I went in and said I had brought the satins—I opened the parcel, and he said, "Oh, these are not satins"—the quiltings were at the top—I said, "No, but the satins are underneath"—he looked at them, and then asked me what price for the whole—I did not say any price—I asked him to give as much as he could—he said he would give 12s. for the whole lot—I said that was very little—he said he did not wish to give more, and I took it—he paid me—no one else was in the shop at the time—I believe this was on Friday evening—there was a light in the shop—the shutters were up—nothing more passed—the day after I went to Mr. Coronel's I was taken into custody at my master's warehouse—I did not upon that make a statement of my conduct in the transaction—I afterwards disclosed what I knew of these robberies—in consequence of which I was taken to Holywell-street by inspector M'Lean, and Evans the warehouse-man—a parcel was made up like the one I had carried to the prisoner—Evans carried it—I saw Evans go into the prisoner's house—I went in first—the prisoner was not in—he came in shortly after, and I pointed him out to Mr. Evans—I was in the shop—I said, "This is the person I sold them to"—I did not hear the prisoner make any observation—I never said in the prisoner's presence what I had sold to him—he was taken in custody—I come from Newgate to give this account to-day.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You are an honest boy in your own eyes, I suppose? A. No—I am speaking the truth—I consider myself a boy of truth—I have told a falsehood—I mean I have told the truth to-day—this is not the first time I have told it—I had some trans
action with Mr. Coronel—when he questioned me in the warehouse I did not tell the truth—I did not tell a word of truth before Mr. Coronel—it was on Thursday night I kept him dodging me from shop to shop—I gave him the slip by going out at the back-door—I knew the house, and had been there before—I went in at the door and told Mr. Coronel to wait for me, in
tending to let him remain in the street while I slipped through the back door—I am not acquainted with many shops at which I can get out at the back—I saw Mr. Coronel at my master's the night I was taken—I knew him—I denied ever having seen him in my life—that was the first falsehood I told about him—every word I said about Mr. Coronel was untrue—when I went to sell these things I told the prisoner the truth—I did not tell him I was a warehouseman—I never represented that to anybody—I did not tell the prisoner these were remnants and perquisites which were to be divided among the warehousemen—I could not tell it with truth—I never said so to anybody else—I said so to Mr. Coronel—there was not a word of truth in it—did it to make him buy the goods, to make him think me honest.

Q. Knowing at the time that there was hardly a greater rogue going at large than yourself? A. Yes, that is the truth—the first things I stole were those I sold to the prisoner—as I got into Holywell-street, the thought first flashed across me—I am very sorry now that I sold him things stolen from my master—I was sorry when I reflected on it—it was about a week after I sold to the prisoner that I tried to sell to Coronel—I tried to sell twelve lengths of figured velvet—I offered them for sale at a shop in New
ington—they bought them—I went into another shop before that—no other—the shop where I gave Mr. Coronel the slip is in St. Martin's-lane—I had often been there for my master—I never attempted to sell any thing there—it is Mr. Ferguson's droper—we called at three other shops

that night—I called at Mr. Ferguson's for a bag—I had some velvets with me—I did not intend to sell them—it was not the velvet I offered to Coronel—I had brought them from a Mr. Freeman's, opposite Mr. Ferguson's, to put into the bag—I kept Coronel waiting for me at three houses—I did not tell him I was going to sell things—I told him I went to take a parcel to the master of the shop—I had three parcels with me—I had those par
cels with my master's knowledge—I had three shops to call at with my master's knowledge—I bad three parcels in all—I had not all three with my master's knowledge—I had two with his knowledge—I never gave a false address to any body—I did not tell Coronel that I lived in Bread-street—I swear that—I never mentioned Bread-street to him—the prisoner's door was open when I went in—the shop was shut—any body could have gone in and seen me there, and what I was about—I was in the shop when the parcel of quiltings was found which I had sold to him about a week before—it was lying on the back counter—there were plenty of places of concealment in the shop—it was found tied up in the brown-paper parcel in which I had sold it—the prisoner did not ask me my address—I swear that—I did not give him "Bread-street"—I had no object in deceiving the prisoner—I deceived Coronel because he wanted to know how I got them—I did not tell Coronel where I lived—he asked me—I did not tell him "Bread-street," or anywhere—I made him no answer—he then put on his hat, and came after me—I swear I never mentioned Bread-street to him—I never gave my address as "Bread-street" to any one—always the true one—I could have given Coronel a false address, but I did not—I did not like to tell an untruth—I did not deceive Mr. Coronel—I have dealt with Jones at Newington—I am a witness against him—it was out of sorrow for my sins that I turned witness, no other reason—I do not exactly under
stand you—I wished Mr. Saltmer to have his property back—I told of this before I was threatened to be prosecuted.

Q. On your solemn oath, did you tell one word until you were promised not to be prosecuted yourself? A. Yes, I did—Cuthbert told me that my master would not prosecute me if I told—I answered you before without thinking—my memory came back after seeing Cuthbert—I was not afraid he would contradict me—I said it quite in mistake—I understand the question—I do not know that it was to get off myself that I told the story—Cuthbert told me, over and over again, that I should be prosecuted unless I gave evidence—it was after that I told the story against the prisoner—I did not tell Cuthbert a word till he told me I should not be prosecuted—it is to save myself that I have come to give evidence, and also from sorrow for my sins, both—I do not think about being safe—I should not have told any thing unless I had thought I should be safe—I believe I should have done so now, because I am very sorry for it.

Q. Do you care how many you convict, provided you get off yourself? A. I do not wish them to be hurt—I do not wish them to be convicted—if the Jury do not believe me, I think I should run the risk of being pro
secuted—I wish to convict the prisoner that I may save myself—whether I am prosecuted or not depends very much upon whether he is convicted; and the same with respect to Jones, if the Jury do not convict, I think I run the risk of being tried myself.

MR. BODKIN. Q. When you left Coronel what house did you first go to? A. Mr. Milie's, in St. Martin's-lane—I believe he is a woollen-draper—he is a customer of my master's—I took a parcel there on my muster's business—I went from there to Mr. Freeman's, a customer of my

master's—I had to fetch some velvets from there—I then went to Mr. Ferguson's, and took the velvets there which I got from Mr. Freeman's, to put into my master's bag, which was there, to take them home—Mr. Ferguson's house has a front and back door.

RICHARD EVANS . I am foreman to the prosecutor, who has premises in Friday-street. I heard of Coronel's coming to the warehouse the next morning, in consequence of which I spoke to M'Knight—he made a statement to me—Mr. Saltmer was not there—he came in about an hour afterwards—M'Knight's father was present—Mr. Saltmer gave M'Knight two hours to consider to tell me all—at the expiration of the two hours I went and fetched Cuthbert, and Inspector M'Lean was sent for—some patterns were pointed out to me by M'Knight, which I have here—he pointed out these figured satins with respect to the prisoner—they are worth about 6s. a yard—I have examined the stock, and three pieces of that pattern, of nine yards each, are missing—I afterwards went with M'Knight and the Inspector to Holy well-street—a parcel was made up to carry—M'Knight went in first and I followed him—the prisoner came in in about three minutes, and M'Knight said, "That is the man I sold the goods to"—I did not hear the prisoner make any observation—I di
rectly came out to the inspector, who was outside—when he came in, the prisoner said, "I suppose this boy has been stealing these goods which I bought?"—the inspector then came in—he said, "Come, I want these goods"—he muttered something—the inspector went round, the parcel was Jying there, and he took possession of it—it contained the black quiltings produced—I then asked him where the figured satins were—he said he had never seen them—the inspector searched about, but found nothing more—he was taken into custody and brought away.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. And afterwards bailed that same night, was he not? A. He was—these quiltings are cotton and silk—it is used for facing coats and waistcoats—this is very different—that might be bought for 18d., when this is 10s. 6d.—this is all cotton—I should say there is very little silk in it, if any—we do not keep any tiling of that sort—the prisoner muttered something I did not understand—the officer went round the counter and took up these black things—it is a small shop—they laid on the back counter in paper—I cannot say whether it was the paper they were sold in—when the officer said, "I want the things," the prisoner did not say, "They are there on the counter, in that paper"—he muttered something about remnants—he said they were remnants—he did not point to them when he muttered—M'Knight said, "I think these are them"—it is a dark shop, and they were on the back counter—the prisoner said in answer to the officer's question, that those were the only goods he had ever seen from him, and he knew nothing of the satins—we made a search, but never found a bit of satin.

JAMES DICKONS SALTMER . I am an importer and dealer in foreign silks, and live in Friday-street. Evans has given a correct value of the silks, the patterns of which he showed in the book—I know these three lengths of nine yards each are missing from the stock—they are 6s. a yard—these quiltings have been missed from the stock—two lengths are worth 10s. 6d. a yard—there are four yards and a half of that—one length, about two yards, worth 7s. a yard; another, about three yards, worth 7s. —the value of them is taken at an average—there is 4l. 2s. 3d. worth found, as part of what was sold at 12s.,—I have given the price at which

we have sold them—that is the wholesale price—perhaps the retailer may be satisfied with 1s. a yard profit—they are chiefly sold to tailors—I have a customer named Milie, in Warwick-street, and Freeman and Ferguson, in St. Martin's-lane—I believe on the day M'Knight went to Coronel he had to go to those customers for me.

Q. Did you at any time before he was taken into custody, notice his leaving the warehouse carrying any thing with him? A. I did on one occasion—one evening when I returned from the West-end about seven o'clock, he was about returning home, and had a small brown paper parcel—he took it up, but I did not notice that he took it out—my suspicions were not excited.

FRANCIS M'LEAN . I am inspector of the police. I was called to the prosecutor's premises on the 19th of November, and took M'Knight into custody—in consequence of what he had said it was arranged that I should go with him to Holy well-street—Evans carried a parcel—I went into the shop after Evans and M'Knight, as Evans beckoned me, and I found the prisoner there—I had scarcely entered the shop before I observed a brown paper parcel at the back part of the shop, on the counter—I took it and showed it to Evans—it was not tied up, but folded up in brown-paper—I showed it to Evans, and asked if he could identify it—he immediately said he could—I said to the prisoner, "Where is the rest of the things?"—a conversation passed between Evans and him, which I did not hear, being engaged watching the shop—he seemed in a very great deal of trouble, and his wife too, we could hardly keep her quiet—I did not hear him make any answer when I said, "Where is the rest of the things?"—I searched the house as well as the shop, but found nothing of the prosecutor's.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Although you did not hear him say any thing, you will not swear he did not? A. Oh dear no.
(The prisoner received a most excellent character.)
NOT GUILTY .
(See Surrey Cases, page 234.)

div0.p: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
235.
THOMAS MAJOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of De
cember, 10 cheroots, value 2s., the goods of
James Essex.

JAMES ESSEX . I live in Park-street, Camden-town, and am a tobac
conist. I missed some cheroots at a quarter before eleven o'clock on the morning of the 2nd of December—I had seen them safe about a quarter of an hour before I missed them—I received information, went after the prisoner, and found him with these cheroots in his jacket pocket, they are the exact quantity I had lost—they exactly corresponded with mine.
CAROLINE ESSEX . On the 2nd of December the prisoner came into the shop—he bought some cigars—immediately after he went I missed this bundle of cheroots.

GUILTY .* Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

236.
WILLIAM SKINNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of December, 11lbs. weight of leaden-pipe, value 1s. 2d., the goods of
Lewis Lewis .

LEWIS LEWIS . I am an ironmonger, and live in Crawford-street—the prisoner worked for me occasionally—I sent him into the front area to repair a cistern, on the 2nd of December—he came up and asked me for some money to get some compo'—I saw a bit of leaden-pipe in his cloth—I took it out and found it was mine—I then missed it.

Prisoner. I did not intend to take it away. Witness. It was wrapped up in his cloth with some tools—I said, "What have you there?"—he said, "My tools"—I then found this—he said, "Pray, forgive me, it is my first time."
JURY. Q. Where was the lead kept? A. In the front kitchen, which was used as a warehouse—he was working as a bricklayer—he is not a plumber.

GUILTY . Aged 64.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Two Months.

237.
JOHN STEED and
MICHAEL SULLIVAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of November, 1 coat, value 18s., the goods of
Thomas Harding.

THOMAS HARDING . I am an excavator, and live at Paddington. On Wednesday afternoon, the 11th of November, at half-past three o'clock, I left my coat in my cart, at the side of the road, while I went to look at my men—I missed it.

RICHARD HOPCROFT . I was in the prosecutor's employ. I heard an alarm about half-past three o'clock, and ran after the prisoners—they were together—they ran across Nottinghill-park—they turned their heads, and saw me running—Steed threw the coat from his left arm—I caught him at the bottom of the hill—a man who followed me picked the coat up, and brought it to my master's.
Steed's Defence. I had been to Bayswater to look after a job—I did not drop it.

STEED—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

SULLIVAN—
NOT GUILTY .

238.
MICHAEL SHEEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of December, 1 cloak, value 12s., the goods of
William Elliott.

ALEXANDER ANDERSON . I am assistant to William Elliott, of New Church-street, Marylebone. On the evening of the 2nd of December, I was waiting on two ladies in the shop—I received information, and went out—I saw the prisoner running, with a cloak under his arm, which was my master's—I had seen it safe ten minutes before.

GEORGE BREMBLY . I was standing at the corner of Church-street, within two or three doors of the prosecutor's shop. I saw the prisoner running across the road into the Edgware-road, from the prosecutor—the assistant called, "Stop him"—I ran and stopped him.
Prisoner's Defence. The cloak was given to me by a gentleman to take care of—I did not steal it.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined One Year.

239.
WILLIAM BENNETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of December, 1 leather housing, value 5s., the goods of
Mark Rawlinson.
MARK RAWLINSON ., I am a carman, living in Shoe-lane. About a

quarter to five o'clock, in the evening of the 1st of December, I left my cart—I had a leather housing on my horse—in consequence of what a boy told me, I ran after the prisoner, and saw him running with the housing under his arm—he dropped it—I picked it up—he was stopped—I am sure he is the man.

Prisoner. I was coming through Neville's-court, another man met me, asked what I wanted—this man came up with the leather in his hand, and said I stole it—I said, "I will wait till the policeman comes," which I did for five minutes. Witness. There was another man with him, who ran away, but the prisoner is the man who dropped this—the other man was on before me—the prisoner was on before him.
GEORGE CANNON . I saw the prisoner running up Neville's-court, and after he turned the corner, he dropped it—I am sure he is the man who dropped it.

GUILTY .* Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

240.
