JAMES OGLEBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of December, 1 trowel, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Lucas.

THOMAS LUCAS . I am assistant to my father, James Lucas, a builder, in Cromer-street. About twelve o'clock, on the 2nd of December, I left my trowel inside the second-floor window of a house in Monmouth-street—I missed it—this now produced is it.

JOHN O'BRIEN . I am a broker, and live in Monmouth-court. Between two and three o'clock, on the 2nd of December, the prisoner came to me with this trowel, and asked me to buy it—I asked where he got it—he said he had picked it up in the street—he was taken the next day—I went to the station, and took the trowel.
WILLIAM MASON (police-constable G 127.) I took the prisoner into custody from Mr. Lucas's description.

GUILTY .* Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

241.
DAVID EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of No
vember, 1 stove, value 7s., the goods of
John Weeks.

JOHN WEEKS . I am a smith, living in Church-street, Bethnal-green. Between seven and eight o'clock, on the 24th of November, I missed a stove—I went out, and found the prisoner and two others in four or five minutes after—the prisoner had the stove on his shoulder.
WILLIAM ELLIOTT . I was walking by the prosecutor's shop—I saw three lads standing at the door—I walked on, turned, and saw the prisoner put the stove on his shoulder.
Prisoner. Q. What did I do with it? A. You went across the road, and turned down a turning—I did not see a man give it you.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry it to Whitechapel—he put it on my shoulder.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

242.
WILLIAM MURRELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of November, 1 jacket, value 11s.; and 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; the goods
James Weedon, the younger.

JAMES WEEDON . Jun. I lodge at Ruislip. On the 24th of November, I had a velveteen jacket and waistcoat lying on my bed in my sleeping-room—the prisoner was a labourer in the same place, and lodged with me —I got up early on the morning of the 25th of November, and they were gone—these produced are them.

RICHARD DAVIS . I am a pawnbroker, and produce the jacket and waistcoat. The prisoner came to me on Friday week—he said his mother bad bought him a jacket, and it was too small—I got these from the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw a bundle by the roadside, and found these things in it—I went to Davis's, and swopped them away with him, and when I heard it was lost, I went and asked Mr. Davis to let me have them again.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

243.
ANN PARSONS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

244.
CHARLES CURTIS was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of November, 44lbs. weight of lead, value 5s., the goods of
Benjamin Dra
per; and
JAMES WATERS
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

BENJAMIN DRAPER . I am a plumber, living at Hounslow. On the 20th of November, I went to my melting shop—I found the window broken, which led me to suspect the place had been entered—I missed half a cwt. of old lead which had been left in my shop—I informed the police-man —the lead now produced is mine—it was brought to me by Waters on the Tuesday following, the 23rd—he asked me if I would buy some lead—I found it belonged to me, end the officer took him.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDEROAST. Q. Half a cwt. is rather heavy for inch a lad as Curtis to carry? A. Yes.

CHARLES JEFFS (police-sergeant T 20.) I received information on the 23rd of November, that the lead had been offered at the prosecutor's house, I took Curtis into custody on the 20th—I saw some footsteps—I compared them with Curtis's—I took him on suspicion.
NOT GUILTY .

245.
ELIZABETH JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of November, 9 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 5s., the goods of
Edward Jenkins; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY GIBBS . I live with Edward Jenkins in New Church-street, Marylebone. About eleven o'clock on the 30th of November I heard something snatched down—there was some printed cotton hanging inside the door—I went round to the door and saw the prisoner standing there—as soon as I went to the door she left it—I missed one piece of cotton from the place—I followed the prisoner, brought her back, and took this print from her.
THOMAS HASELDINE (police-constable D 104.) I took the prisoner, and have the cotton.

THOMAS HARRISON (police-sergeant D. 14.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the same person—and she had been before convicted of felony.

GUILTY .* Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

246.
FREDERICK GOSLING was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of November, 1 pair of boots, value 8s., the goods of
Israel Foster; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE HOMES . I am in the service of Israel Foster, who keeps a shoe-shop in Lower-street, Islington. I was at home on the 27th of November—I missed a pair of boots—I had seen them safe a quarter of an hour before
—I ran out and saw the prisoner running away with them—I ran after him, and tried to secure him—the policeman came up—he threw the boots away—the policeman took them up, and took him.
THOMAS HOBBS KING (police-sergeant N 22.) I saw the prisoner throw the boots away—I took him.
HENRY BLYTH (police-constable K 302.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

247.
SARAH MEAD was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of November, 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 table-cover, value 1s.; and 2 blankets, value 8s.,; the goods of
Harriet Crighton.
HARRIET CRIGHTON . The prisoner lodged with me—I missed this sheet, table-cover, and two blankets—I sent for a policeman, and found the tickets of them in her room.
Cross-examined by MR. STEPHENS. Q. Did not the prisoner give the tickets to the policeman? A. Yes—she took them from the fire-place—I believe it was done through great distress.
HENRY FOWLER . I am a pawnbroker—I have a blanket pawned by the prisoner.
LAWRENCE LAW . I have a sheet pawned by the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

248.
CAROLINE WILDAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of November, 1 cloak, value 19s., the goods of
Joseph Norbury.

THOMAS BISHOP . I am shopman to Mr. Joseph Norbury, of Crawford-street. On the 11th of November he had a cloak safe inside the shop—it was missed at seven o'clock in the morning, on the 12th—this is the cloak—I made it up.
HENRY FOWLER (police-constable E 111.) I stopped the prisoner in the street with this cloak, at a quarter before nine o'clock in the morning, on the 12th of November.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Edgeware-road—a man asked a woman to buy this cloak—he wanted 10s. for it—she said if she saw him on her way back, she would have it—he ran after her and said she should have it for 8s.—he saw me stop, and said, "Will you buy it?"—I wanted one and bought it—I was going to show it to my friends and was stopped.

HENRY FOWLER
re-examined. She told me she bought it at a shop in Holborn.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

249.
EDWARD COLEMAN,
JOHN RYAN , and
JOHN KEMP were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November, 4 caps, value 3s. 9d., the goods of
William Lance.

JOHN EATON (police-constable S 199.) Between eight and nine o'clock at night, on the 26th of November, I met the three prisoners—they had all new caps on—I had known them before, and knew they had old caps—I saw Coleman separate from the other two, and he had something under his jacket—I took him, and told a butcher to take the other two—I found one of these caps under Coleman's jacket, and this other on his head—the other prisoners had each one of these caps on his head—Coleman said they had found them.
WILLIAM LANCE . I live in High-street, Camden-town—I lost these four caps between half-past six and eight o'clock that evening—I can swear to their being mine.

(Owen Hart and James Harley gave Coleman a good character; Mar
garet Massey and Bridget Preston gave Ryan a good character.)

COLEMAN*—
GUILTY .

RYAN*—
GUILTY .

KEMP†—
GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years.
Convict Ship.

250.
ELIZABETH BEDWORTH was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of November, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 9d., the goods of
Richard Wilcox Fairlam.

FREDERICK LEIGHTON . I am shopman to Mr. Richard Wilcox Fairlam, a pawnbroker in Lisson-grove. On the 19th of November the prisoner came to the shop—I missed a handkerchief when she was gone—I went after her and brought her back—I said, "You have got a handkerchief—she said, "No, I have not"—I said, "You have it in your bosom"—she said, "I have not, you may feel"—I said no, I would get a women, and she pulled it out.
ELIZABETH SACHEVERELL . I was in the shop, and took this handkerchief from the prisoner's bosom.
Prisoner. I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Four Months.

251.
ELLEN HAYS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Novem
ber, 1 frock, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Shine.

SARAH ELIZABETH SHINE . I am the wife, of Thomas Shine—he keeps a shop at Poplar. On the 20th of November the prisoner came, and when she was gone I went after her and told her to come back, as she had something belonging to me—she seemed confused—she came back and threw this frock into my shop—it is my husband's—she has a sick husband, and I believe was in much distress.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Nine Days.

252.
JOHN HOY was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of November, 1 coat, value 16s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1l.; the goods of
Frederick Smith.

FREDERICK SMITH . I live in Rawstorne-street, Clerkenwell—I had a box in my room. I missed a coat and handkerchief from it on the 8th of November, in the evening—they had been safe that morning—these now produced are them—I had not seen the prisoner in the house, but he is a companion of my landlord's son.
WILLIAM LEWIS . I am a pawnbroker. This coat and handkerchief were pawned by the prisoner on the 8th of November, in the name of John Davis.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor gave me the coat, and asked if I would pawn it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

253.
WILLIAM DUNN was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Decem
ber, 1 plane, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Adam Williamson Smart.
ADAM WILLIAMSON SMART . I am a broker, and live in Great Earl-street, Seven Dials. I had this plane safe on the 1st of December, and my wife afterwards missed it—this is it.

JAMES LEWIS ASHMAN (police-constable T 119.) On Wednesday evening the 1st of December I was on duty in Monmouth-street—I saw the prisoner and two others—the prisoner had this plane under his arm—I stopped him and asked where he got it—he said he picked it up in Hale's yard.
Prisoner. I got it from a boy who picked it up.

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Confined Nine Days, and
Whipped.

254.
JAMES SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Novem
ber, 1 coat, value 4s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; and 1 snuff-box, value 6d. the goods of
George Addison.
GEORGE ADDISON . On the 27th of November, about six o'clock, I left my coat on a sieve in Covent-garden-market—in half-an-hour I heard it was gone—I saw it at the office in Bow-street—this is it.

THOMAS RAFFAR . I was at work in Covent-garden-market on Satur
day evening the 27th of November—I saw the prisoner about—I watched him and told the beadle—I saw the prisoner go and take the coat—he went under the piazzas and opened it—I ran and caught him—he threw me down and the officer caught him.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

255.
ELIZA MASLIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of June, 1 bed, value 2l., the goods of
Sarah Weaver.

SARAH WEAVER . I live in Short's-gardens, and am a widow. I let the prisoner a ready-furnished lodging—in consequence of what I heard, I went into her bed-room, and the bed was gone—I told her of it, and she said she would get it by twelve o'clock—I called the policeman, and he took her—she said at the station that she had pawned it, but would not tell where—we cannot find it.
SOPHIA MADDOX . I spoke to the prisoner about this—she said she had pawned the bed, and sold the ticket.

Prisoner. A person that lodged in the back attic pawned it for me, and I do not know where—she is since dead. I was in very great distress, and must have perished if I had not been taken the morning I was.

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Confined Two Months.

256.
JOHN JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Novem
ber, 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Charles de Neve.

CHARLES DE NEVE . I keep the Earl St. Vincent public-house in Tor
rington-street, Torrington-square. This pot is mine—I do not know the prisoner—he had no authority to take it.

JOHN ARMSTRONG (police-constable S 154.) I found this pot on the prisoner on the 27th of November, at half-past eight o'clock in the morn
ing—I asked what he had got—he replied, "Nothing."
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up in the road as I was coming to work.

(The prisoner received a good character; and a witness engaged to em
ploy him.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Days.

257.
CHARLES CAMPBELL was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

RICHARD HAMILTON . I live in John-street, Cornwall-fields, and am a rigger. Between five and six o'clock in the evening of the 29th of Octo
ber, the prisoner came to me—he said his name was Archibald Gibbons, that he had come from Singapore, with his ship, and he was very glad he had found a decent place—he said he was a sail-maker, and had been out for eighteen months—the name of the ship I could not ascer
tain—he said all his things were to be fetched up next day, and he had about 50l. to take as wages for the voyage of eighteen months—he said he wanted the loan of 4s. or 5s. to go to see his shipmates, and to treat them—I told him 4s. or 5s. was rather too much for him to spend, as it was late in the evening—he said, "Give me 3s.," which I did, and away he went—it was on account of these representations, and saying he was so very happy he had fallen in with a countryman of his, or I would not have done it.

JOHN CRIGHTON . I live at Gold's-hill, and keep a lodging-house. On the 29th of October the prisoner came to me about half-past eight o'clock at night—he said he had come home from Singapore, and had eighteen months' money to receive—he was happy to think he had come to a de
cent, respectable house, and to a countryman of his—he asked me for a pint of rum—I would not let him hare it—I gave him some beer, and he went to bed—next morning he got 3s., and said he was going to see his shipmates at the Sailors' Home to know When they were going on board for their things—I went with him to the Home—he went in and came out, and said they were gone on a cruize.

Q. But what pretence did he make when he got the money? A. He got it after breakfast, on the 30th, and told me he would pay it back again when he got the money—he told me his wages were due, and asked for some money to go to see his shipmates—I desired my wife to give it him—I should not have done so if he had not said he had this money due to him.

MARY SAKEY . The prisoner was brought to my house on the 6th of November—he said he wanted a lodging where he should be comfortable and safe—he said he wanted his clothes fetched up, as he had come off a voyage, and should be paid on Thursday—after he had sat a bit, be said his ship lay at No. 4, West India Dock, that he came from Singapore, in the Ann Anna, and that he had been carpenter on board—he said, "Can you lend me a shilling or eighteen-pence?"—I said, "Yes," and told the money out of my pocket—he took a half-crown, and said that would do—I should not have let him have it if he had not said he came from Singa
pore, and that this money was due to him.

JAMES DIXON . I am superintendent of the East and West India Docks. There is no such ship as the Ann Anna, nor has there been for the last two years, and there has been no ship in the East and West India Docks from Singapore.

Prisoner's Defence. I came home in the John M'Duff, from Singapore—I asked Mr. Hamilton for a lodging, and he gave me 3s.—I asked Mrs. Sakey's son if he would come down with me—I asked her for a shilling, and I had at the same time 6s. 6d. in my pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There were nine other charges against the prisoner at the Police Court.)

258.
ABRAHAM RUST was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of No
vember, 2 tame geese, price 10s., the property of
Samuel Aveline.
SAMUEL AVELINE . I live at Holloway down, Laytonstone, in the parish of Layton. On the 29th of November I had three geese—I found two dead, one on the premises, and one in a field adjoining my house.

DANIEL SHINE . On the 29th of November, at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was on my beat at Holloway-down—when I got opposite to the prosecutor's house, I heard a goose make a noise—I came to the gate in front of the house, and saw the prisoner standing close by an out-house—I went to the place where he stood, and found the door of the out-house open, and the prisoner inside—I took him into custody—he had not got any thing—I asked what brought him there—he did not give me any dis
tinct answer—I called at the prosecutor's house, which was about four or five yards off—somebody answered me from the window, and in a little time Mr. Aveline came out, and we took the prisoner to the station—I then came back, searched, and found a dead goose in a field close to the house, about seven or eight yards from where I took the prisoner—I did not find any other goose myself—I searched the prisoner, and found no
thing on him—the neck of the goose I found was broken—I do not know whether it was warm—it was quite flexible.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. It was the cackling that at
tracted your attention? A. Yes—it lasted about two minutes—it was in the out-house—I had to climb over a gate to get to it—it was moon-light—I suspected there was something wrong with the geese at the time, and went as fast as I could—the prisoner did not tell me he had heard the cackling.

JANE AVELING . Between eleven and twelve o'clock at night I saw the policeman get over the gate—I opened the window, and asked what he wanted—he said there was a man in the out-house—I then went to the back part of the house, opened another window close to the out-house, and there saw the policeman with the prisoner in custody—I went down stairs, opened the door, and admitted him—after the prisoner was taken to the station I went with my son to the out-house, and found a dead goose there —I did not see the goose that was found in the field—I had not locked the out-house that evening, but I saw that all the bolts were secured—there had been three geese there—I found one there still alive.
Cross-examined. Q. Do not geese make a great noise if there is any thing the matter in the night? A. They have done so.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined One Month.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

259.
EDWARD STANBROOK and
CHARLES SMITH were in
dieted for
stealing, on the 16th of November, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
John Wright; to which they pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Confined Three Months.

260.
ELIZABETH TANDY was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of October, 1 pair of gloves, value 1s. 9d., the goods of
Matthew Aylett, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

261.
PHILIP SPARKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of November, 30lbs. weight of potatoes, value 1s., the goods of
Samuel Cornell.

SAMUEL CORNELL . I am a farmer, and live at Hill Farm, Woodford-bridge, Essex. On the 17th of November I went to Romford—I returned, and received information about the prisoner, who had been in my employ for about seven years—I had directed him that morning to put two sacks of potatoes into my cellar—I got a policeman, and went and found the pri
soner in the road with a bag of potatoes—I examined them—they were exactly like what I had in my cellar—the sacks in my cellar were defi
cient in quantity—I found thirty pounds of potatoes in the prisoner's bag, but I missed more than that.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you measure the pota
toes that were left in the cellar? A. No, but I could tell that I missed more than 1cwt.

ELIZA MOTT . I am in the prosecutor's service. On the 17th of No
vember I was in the dairy, and saw the prisoner employed in taking pota
toes into the cellar—I noticed, when he came up from the. cellar, that he had some potatoes in a sack on his back—he then emptied them out of the tack into a bag—the sack was such a one as my master uses for potatoes—I told my master when he came home.
GEORGE ABRAHAM MOORE (police-constable K 76.) I went with the prosecutor, and met the prisoner with the potatoes on his shoulder—I asked where he got them from—he said from where he worked.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

262.
WILLIAM SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of October, 2 spades, value 6s.; 1 kettle, value 5s.; 1 pair of shears, value 2s.; 1 stew-pan, value 3s.; and 1 sack, value 2s.; the goods of
William Ackhurst; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 31,—
Confined Three Months.

263.
WILLIAM WOOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of No
vember, 10 shillings and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Robert William Greener, his master.

ROBERT WILLIAM GREENER . I am a fishmonger, and live at Deptford; the prisoner was in my employ about four or five months. On the 19th of October he went out with goods, and all the money he took he made away with, and I discharged him on the 20th for doing so—I afterwards took him back again—he remained about eleven days—I was to give him 6d. a

week, find him lodging, and give him two-thirds of what he earned—if he earned 6s. I gave him 4s. out of it—I sent him to market to buy fish, and when he sold it he should bring the money to me—on the 2nd of Novem
ber I gave him ten shillings, and two sixpences, and he was to receive 1s., from a salesman in the Borough-market, which was left on some baskets—I saw him the same morning, and he said he had received it—he never brought me the money—I saw him no more till I gave him in charge, two days after—he said nothing till he was taken before the Magistrate—I have four lads in my employ.

Prisoner. He gave me so much money to go to market with, and for every shilling I earned I had to give him 4d. for the use of it. Witness. I deny it—I never lent him any money—he was my weekly servant—I gave him two-thirds of the profits.

JOSEPH GREIG (police-constable R 107.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody on Thursday, the 4th of November—I told him I took him for rob
bing his master of 12s.—he said he had lost half-a-crown of the money, and did not like to come home—I only found three halfpence on him.
Prisoners Defence. He gave me 11s.—to go to market with; lost Half-a-crown in the Borough-market, and did not like to come home with the rest.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

264.
JABEZ WATTS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Novem
ber, 1 hat, value 11s., the goods of
Thomas William Tanner.

ISAIAH BOND (police-constable R 99.) On the 24th of November, about ten o'clock, I was on duty, and stopped the prisoner with this hat—he said he had stolen it from a shop—I took him to Mr. Tanner's, a hatter in Church-street, and they claimed the hat—I did not know him before.

CHARLES JAMES CHURCHER . I am shopman to Mr. Thomas William Tanner, a hatter, at Greenwich. This is his hat—I had seen it safe at five minutes past nine o'clock, on the counter in the shop, about two yards from the door.
(The prisoner pleaded poverty.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Weeks.

265.
WILLIAM LYALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of October, 1 knife, value 1s., the goods of
William Jiggins.

WILLIAM JIGGINS . I am a malster, at Mr. Page's Brewery, Greenwich. On the 31st of October I left my breeches in the malt-house, and a knife in the pocket—when I returned, between seven and eight o'clock on Monday morning, I missed it—I found it on the 5th of November—this now produced is it—I know the prisoner and his father—he never worked on our premises, but used to come down the yard to see one of the lads.

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable R 49.) I took the prisoner into custody, on the 5th of November, in a beer-shop in Church-street—I found the knife in his pocket—he said he knew he had done wrong, he knew it was Jiggins's knife.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the knife, and had not the least intention of keeping it; I meant to return it to Jiggins again.

WILLIAM JIGGINS
re-examined. I am sure the knife was left in my pocket, and had not fallen out—my breeches were lying at the foot of a bed at Mr. Page's—I slept up stairs—the door below was left open—there was nothing else in the trowsers.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Parke.

266.
ROSINA CRICK was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of No
vember, 2 waistcoats, value 4s.; 1 shirt, value 5s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 17s.; 1 pair of drawers, a fork, and other articles; the goods of
Piercy Ben, her master.

ANTHONY MORRISS . I am servant to Mr. Piercy Ben, a captain in the Royal Artillery, quartered at Woolwich—the prisoner was my fellow-ser
vant. On the 22nd of November, about the middle of the day, she told me she had been discharged—I afterwards saw her bring a bundle down stairs, wrapped in something white—I saw her carry it to the door, and give it to a boy, and the boy left the house—I followed, and brought him back—she took the bundle from him, went into the house again, locked the door after her, and left me outside—soon after I saw her bring another bundle, carry it to the back door, and return without it—I went up stairs from the kitchen, and was ordered to fasten the doors—I fastened the back door, and while fastening the front, the prisoner walked out—I followed her, and told her to come back—she said she would not—I kept her till the policeman came, and gave her in charge—she desired me to let her go several times—I said I would not—she said she would make away with herself—when she said she had been discharged, she said she had not been paid her wages, and she had told her mistress that she might leave it with me, and she would call at my quarters for it the day after—I saw the bundles after they were opened—she had no bundle with her when I said I would give her in charge—I believe the bundles I saw examined at the house to be those I saw her with a few minutes before.

MARY MORRISS . I am the wife of the last witness, and am occasionally servant to Captain Ben. On the 22nd of November, between ten and eleven o'clock in the day, I was employed there—I heard Captain Ben give the prisoner notice—she was discharged at a moment's notice—she af
terwards told me she was discharged from the service—I saw her go up to her room after that—I followed her, and saw her take a large bundle from under her bed—she put some more things into it, and brought it down stairs—I heard her tell Mrs. Ben, she was ready to go, and Mrs. Ben told her to wait till the captain returned, and she would pay her her wages—the prisoner said if she would give it to my husband she would call next day for the money—she had put the things into the bundle be
fore she said any thing to her mistress about her wages, and she took it out—I told her Mrs. Ben wished to see the things she had—the bundle was in the passage—she brought it into the hall and opened it—there were some pieces of chintz which I know to be Mrs. Ben's property, also some pillow-cases, a shirt, and pair of stockings, and Captain Ben's trowsers—she had been three months and two days in the service—a pair of drawers were found upon her at the police-station—I believe the bundle I saw in the hall was the bundle I saw her take from under the bed—there was another bundle tied up in it—the two bundles were made into one.

MARIA HILL . lam female-searcher at the station. On Monday the 22nd, when the prisoner was brought in, I searched her, and found a fork in her bosom—she said, "O Lord, what have I done in my flurry, put this in my bosom!"—I also found a pair of men's flannel drawers on her person—she was wearing them—she said they were her husband's, and she wore them because she had the rheumatism.
GEORGE BAKER . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—here are the drawers found on her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. Mrs. Ben asked to see my things—I opened them all to her, and she was perfectly satisfied nothing belonging to her was in the bundle—I went up stairs, dressed, came down, and said, "I am going;" she said, "Very well, you can go, and I will pay you your wages when Captain Ben comes in"—I went down into the kitchen, Mrs. Morriss went up stairs, and said I had got something belonging to her in a bundle; she came down and desired to see the bundle; (I said Mrs. Ben had seen my clothes, and was satisfied nothing of hers was there;) she brought it in, opened it, and these were inside; I know nothing of them, I am innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Weeks.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

267.
ALEXANDER HENDERSON and
ROBERT ADAMSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of October, 220lbs. weight of coals, value 3s., the goods of
Anthony Strother, their master.

ANTHONY STROTHER . I am a coal-merchant, living at Woolwich—the prisoners were in my employ. On the 26th of October, I sent them to Plumpstead-common with two wagons of coals, each containing thirty sacks, and each sack 2341bs.—they returned at half-past ten in the morning—Henderson told me they were all right—I thought that rather singular—Adamson was not present then.

WILLIAM HENRY LOCK . I am in the employ of Mr. Power, at Plump
stead. About half-past six in the morning of the 26th of October, I saw the two prisoners coming with coals—I saw Henderson undo the rope at the back of the wagon—Adamson took a sack, and went in the way to Bull's-fields—Henderson was doing the rope up—Adamson returned with an empty sack under his arm—I then went to work—I undid the gates when the prisoners came to the house, and afterwards found there was a sack deficient —Henderson said to me, "Do you live here?"—I said, "Yes"—he then said, "We are done."

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What time in the morning was this? A. Between half-past six and seven o'clock—it took place about three quarters of a mile from my master's—they had not then taken the coals to my master's—I did not count the sacks till they got to the house—I went straight on to Mr. Power's—I am not in his employ now, I have finished my work—I told my master as soon as he got up—one Bull also was charged with this—he was standing by—he was discharged, and both the prisoners were admitted to bail—Francis Price was not present when they came—he came after—he saw the empty sacks counted—I was directed by the maid
servant to open the gates—I did not tell her what I had seen—I made no complaint that there was any deficiency—I did not tell the prisoners what I had heard them say—I have known Henderson before—Bull was standing at the end of the wagon not doing any thing
—it was on my information he was taken up—he lives at Woolwich as far as I know—he is a respectable man.

WILLIAM LITTLE (police-constable R 205.) I took the prisoners, and Bull was taken by another officer—the coals were said to be taken to a man in Bull's-fields—I took him for receiving the coals—I did not search his house,

MR. BALLANTINE to ANTHONY STROTHER. Q. Did you send out these coals yourself? A. Yes—I know the number of the sacks—I know Price to be the coachman of Mr. Power—Henderson has since been in my ser
vice, on and off nineteen or twenty years, and Adamson about nine months —I did not re
measure the coals on account of something Mr. Power told me.
NOT GUILTY .

268.
ROBERT RUDD was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of Octo
ber, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Mary Allen; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Three Months.

269.
ELIZABETH TURNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of November, 1 blanket, value 3s. 6d.; and 1 set of bed furniture, value 10s.; the goods of
Ann West; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 59.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

270.
ELEANOR ATTWOOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of November, 1 watch, value 1l. 10s.; 1 watch-chain, value 1d.; 2 rings, value 1d.; and 3 watch-keys, value 3d.; the goods of
John Connor.

JOHN CONNOR . I am a Greenwich pensioner. I saw my watch safe on Wednesday, the 3rd of November, in my chest under my bed at Green-wich—I missed it on the Saturday morning—I had sent the prisoner to my chest on Friday, the 5th, to get some bread for tea, about six o'clock—I had seen my watch in the chest about two o'clock that day—she is a capmaker—she drank tea with me on the 4th and on the 5th, but did not drink tea regularly with me.

Prisoner. He told me to pawn the watch—he was drunk. Witness. I did not—I was sober, and was capable of walking as well as at any other time—I had no liquor that day—we had had the beer served out in the College, and had a pot or two of beer, which I gave the prisoner the money, to buy—I suppose she must have taken it when she went for the bread—she passed that night with me—I lived at Chatham, but I never gave her the watch to pawn, either at Chatham, or at Greenwich.

JOHN EVERDEN . I am shopman to Mr. Sharpe, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this watch with me in the morning, on the 6th of Novem
ber, for 15s., in the name of Ellen Connor, a lodger, No. 15, Queen-street, Greenwich—she said it belonged to her husband, who had recently been admitted into the College—I did not know her before.

EDWARD VINCENT (police-constable No. 131.) I was with the prosecutor on the Monday after this happened—the prisoner came up in a state of inebriation, and gave herself up to me, she said she was the woman who had stolen the watch on Friday, and she had pledged it on Saturday, at Mr. Sharpe's, for 15s.

Prisoner's Defence. I came from Maidstone on purpose to see the pro
secutor—I used to live with him in Chatham, and he told me when I was in want of a friend to apply to him.
NOT GUILTY .

271.
WILLIAM GURNEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of October, 4lbs. weight of beef, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Barton, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

272.
GEORGE ROUSE was indicted
for embezzling and stealing 1 Weighing-machine, value 12s., which he had received as servant to, and on account of
Thomas Hunsdon Gore; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Fourteen Days.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

273.
THOMAS BIRCH was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of October, 2 1/2 lbs. weight of coffee, value 4s. 6d.; 1 bottle, value 2d.; 1 pint and a half of wine, value 1s. 6d.; and 2 1/2 lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s. 8d.; the goods of
James Topley, his master.

JAMES TOPLEY . I live at Greenwich. I went to the station at Green-wich, and the policeman told me something—I came with the policeman to my shop, and said to the prisoner, who was my shopman, "The more I go into this business, the more I see you are implicated; the policeman stopped a man with coffee and ginger-wine, and you stated you were the master of the shop, and caused the man to be discharged"—we searched the prisoner's box, and found nothing there but a document in his waist-coat pocket, which corresponded with the things the man had the day be
fore—here is the document, it is in his own handwriting—I came down, and showed him the document, and said, "Is not this your handwriting?"—he said it was—I said, "Is not the man that I saw in the cell at the station, your brother?"—he said, "No—he is my brother-in-law, and the woman in the shop is my mother"—he said he was very sorry, and it should be made up to me if I would let him off—I was talking about the goods that had been given to the man—I asked him what customer had been four or five days before, and paid for these goods—he did not offer to deny it then—he said he was very sorry for it, and it should be made up to me if I would not have him locked up—he said the goods the man was let off for, had been bought and paid for by a regular customer in London—I asked what regular customer I served in London, who would tell their son to call four or five days afterwards for goods—I said I should have found an entry in my book, and there was no entry—I know the things were parted with from the evidence of the policeman.

ELIZABETH COX . I was in Mr. Topley's shop on the 27th of October —the policeman came in, and asked the prisoner if he was master of the shop—he said he was—the policeman asked him if he had served any Per
son that morning with more than lib. of coffee—he said yes he bad served a young man with 2 1/2 lb. of coffee, a bottle of ginger wine, some bacon and sugar, and the policeman said he had not got the sugar when he was stopped.
JAMES CONNOR (police-constable R 191.) On the 27th of October I
was on duty in the Broadway, Deptford, I found on a person some coffee, wine, and bacon—that person was let go, as the prisoner said he was master of the shop.
NOT GUILTY .

274.
CATHERINE SULLIVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of December, 5 dishes, value 1s. 10d.; and 1 basin, value 2d.; the goods of
George Beaver.

GEORGE BEAVER . I keep a broker's shop, and a stall, in Greenwich market. On the 2nd of December, about seven o'clock in the evening, I missed some dishes and a basin from the stall, which were safe a quarter of an hour before—these now produced are them.
ANN BETTLES . About twenty minutes or a quarter before seven o'clock that evening, I saw the prisoner go to the stall, and take three of these dishes—I followed and took hold of her.
Prisoner. I did it from poverty—it is my first offence.

GUILTY . Aged 49.—
Confined One Month.

275.
JOHN ARBUTHNOTT was indicted
for an assault.
NOT GUILTY .

276.
SARAH ROACH and
MARY BRYANT were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of May, 18 yards of ribben, value 13s., the goods of
John Dennis and another.

CHARLES SIMPRINGHAM . I am shopman to John Dennis and Son, of Tooley-street. On the 18th of May, between four and five o'clock, the prisoners came into the shop, and the shopwoman showed them several boxes of linen—as I went round the counter she said to me, "p s q," which is a term we use when we see anybody in the shop doing wrong—they left the shop—we afterwards missed a piece of ribbon, which the policeman brought to the shop about eight o'clock that evening—I know the ribbon produced to be ours—I had it in my hands between twelve and one o'clock that day, and cut the edges to trim it, and noticed it was faded a short length in—how it got from the shop I do not know.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When did you cut the edge? A. About nine o'clock that morning—I swear to it by the style of ribbon, and it being faded—I went before the Grand Jury in Surrey about this, and was in Court when the charge was read over to the prisoner—the charge was not gone into there—I believe that was the fault of the clerk.

COURT. Q. If you preferred an indictment there, how came you here on the same charge? A. We knew the parties were frequently at our shop—the policeman did not tell me to Come here—my employers said they knew their characters to be bad, and they deserved punishment—I knew they had been imprisoned six months for another offence, from the Surrey Sessions—I think we came before the Grand Jury here the next Sessions.
Q. Having a bill found in Surrey, and not tried, why prefer another bill here? A. It was my employers' wish, as we often missed things
after they had been at the shop—they knew I had been to the Surrey Sessions—the young woman who served the prisoners is not here.

JOHN TIDMARSH (police-constable N 51.) On the 15th of May I was on duty in Tooley-street about half-past six o'clock in the evening, and saw the prisoners about fifty yards from the prosecutor's house—I followed and saw them go into a tailor's shop there—they came out—I went in and came out—they saw me following them, and Bryant offered a bundle which she had to Roach, who refused it—I took them in charge—I asked Bryant who the bundle belonged to, and what it contained—she said it did not belong to her—I asked Roach if it was hers—she said not—I found it contained a gown-piece and this roll of ribbon—the witness did not describe any mark on it.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you before the Grand Jury at Horsemonger-lane? A. Yes—I was in Court there when the charge was read over to the prisoners—the clerk forgot this indictment till after they were convicted and sentenced on a first indictment—we came here the next Session and preferred a bill—I cannot tell why we did not go to the Surrey Ses
sion—I have not told them to send the depositions here—I did not consult the Magistrate about it—he said this was a harsh proceeding—a note was sent to the superintendent for me to attend here—I was ordered to attend.
NOT GUILTY .

277.
ANN PARSLEY was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JOHN RED BURN . I am shopman to John and Richard Davis. On the 7th of September the prisoner came to the shop and said she wanted some goods for Mrs. Souter, of Newington—I had seen her in the shop before, and knew her at that time to come from Mrs. Souter—I served her with twelve yards of delaine, eight yards and a half of thread lace, two table-cloths, twelve yards of sheeting, and goods, altogether amounting to 4l. 3s. 1d.—I believed she was still in Mrs. Souter's service—I furnished the goods on Mrs. Souter's account—she said the goods were to be booked to Mrs. Souter, of Newington.

REBECCA SOUTER . I am the wife of Thomas Souter. The prisoner was in my service, and left four years ago last May—I never authorized her to order goods in my name after leaving me—I did not authorize her to go to Mr. Davis's for these goods.
Prisoner.—Distress drove me to it.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month.

278.
HENRY PLEDGE was indicted
for embezzling the sums of 2l. 2s. and 16s., the monies of
Emanuel Jeffery his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—(The prisoner received a good character.)—Recommended to mercy—
Confined Two Months.
Before Mr. Baron Alderson.

279.
JEREMIAH NEALE was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Patrick John Kennedy on the 16th of November, and cutting and wound
ing him upon his head and left side of his neck, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

PATRICK JOHN KENNEDY . I am a labourer, and live at Pail-and-Pun
cheon-court, Bermondsey, in the same house as the prisoner. On Monday

the 15th of November I was in bed—I had been asleep, and was awoke by the prisoner touching my toe—I got out of bed and made towards him, and made a blow at him—he fell, not in consequence of my blow, but to hide himself—he was very much in liquor—when I laid down again he wanted me to go and fight with him outside in the court—I said I did not want to fight him, if he wanted fighting I would talk to him in the morning when he was sober—that would not satisfy him, he wanted to light right or wrong—he said if I did not fight him I had no business to sleep, and he would cut our heels and our ancles off—there were other lodgers in the room, but they were asleep—I said nothing—I knew I had no business to stop in the room when he said this, and I dressed myself and went down stairs—he had gone down before me—when I got down I found him outside the door—he asked me what I wanted—I said I wanted no quarrelling but to go to bed—I then asked what he wanted—he said, "Come on, I am ready for you"—he was making towards me—I defended him off by striking him somewhere in the face with my fist—I cannot say where, I struck him a hard blow—his face did not bleed—I did not give him a black eye—I bit him about the mouth I believe—I did not knock his teeth out—he then struck me over the eye with a knife, and after
wards cut me down the back of the neck and over my left ear—the policeman parted us—I was instantly taken to Guy's Hospital, and got my head dressed.
Prisoner. Q. You saw no knife in my hand? A. I felt it scratching down my neck—I could not see it—it was too dark.

THOMAS MICKEY (police-constable M 152.) I was passing the court, and heard a cry of "Take the knife away from him!—he has got a knife!—murder!—he is killing me with a knife!"—another voice said, "There is a policeman at the top, why not call him?"—I went up, and found the pro
secutor on the prisoner—they both had hold of each other—he said, "Po
liceman, he has got a knife in his hand; take it"—I caught hold of him, and saw his left hand drawn out of his left pocket—I said, "Where is the knife?"—he said, "I have got no knife"—I put my hand into his left pocket, and found this knife—it was shut, and was not bloody—there was a good deal of blood from the wound, all over the prosecutor's shoulder and frock—I saw the prisoner fumbling in his pocket before he drew his hand out—I did not look at the point to see if it was bloody—I took him to the station.

PETER LAY . I am a dresser at Guy's Hospital. I saw the prosecutor when he was brought in—he had three or four small wounds, and one cut behind his left ear—the cuts appeared to be done with a knife—I think this knife would do it—there was not the least danger from the wounds—there had been some bleeding, not much—the knife would not necessarily have been bloody if it had inflicted the wound.

Prisoner's Defence. That night, as I was going to bed, I chanced to put my hand on this man's bed, as it was so near mine; he told me to mind what I was about or he would knock me down stairs; I said he should not do it: he got up, shoved me across the bed, and said, if I wanted any thing to come down stairs, and he would give it me; he was drunk as well as me; when we got down stairs he struck me, and I struck him; a witness stood by, and hallooed out to him, "Do you think he has got a knife?" I had got a knife in my pocket, but I never used it or took it out at all. If it was not a couple of pins I had in the cuff of my jacket that did it, I do not know what else it was.

PATRICK JOHN KENNEDY
re-examined. I had no quarrel with the pri
soner before—he is a very good-tempered man when he is sober—I have known him seven years, and never knew him in any trouble before.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

280.
MARY JACKSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of April, 1 sovereign, 5 shillings, 11 pence, and 1 halfpenny, the monies of
George John Lloyd, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Judgment Respited.

281.
JAMES HOLLANDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of No
vember, 1 jacket, value 6s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
Robert Bennington, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

ROBERT BENNINGTON . I am a sailor on board the brig Durdon, which was lying in the Commercial Dock at Rotherhithe. On the 4th of No
vember, about a quarter-past nine o'clock, I missed my jacket from the forecastle, where I had seen it five minutes before.

CAROLINE CAVENDON . On the 4th of November, about half-past eleven o'clock, the prisoner came to my lodging at Deptford, and asked whether the landlord belonging to the house was in—the mistress said he was not, did he want him?—he said, "Not particularly"—after he had been there two or three minutes, he asked me if I would go on an errand for him—I said "Yes"—he took off his short frock which he wore, took off this jacket, and asked me to go and pledge it for him, which I did, at Mr. Tighe's, in the Broadway, for 2s., which I gave to the prisoner—our house is about two miles and a half from the Commercial Dock.

JOHN TIGHE . I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Broadway, Deptford. I produce a jacket which was pawned with me by Cavendon, on the 4th of November, for 2s., in the name of "James Holland"—she told me she was pawning it for a man of that name—it was before dinner-time.

WILLIAM GEORGE OSBORN . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on the 4th of November—a man named Cobham was also taken—the prisoner said he knew more about the jacket—that the other man knew nothing at all about it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I met a man by the Surrey Canal, who asked if I wanted to buy a jacket; I said "Yes;" he wanted 3s.; I had only 2s., which I gave him, and said, if I saw him again I would give him the other shilling.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

282.
MICHAEL CONLON was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Mary Bridget Mahoney, on the 12th of September, and cutting and wound
ing her upon the top, forepart, and right-side of her head, with intent to murder her.—3 other COUNTS, stating his intent to be to maim, disfigure, or to do her some grievous bodily harm.
MESSRS. CLARKSON and DOANE conducted the Prosecution.
MARY BRIDGET MAHONEY . I am single, and live with Mr. Allman, in Upper Stamford-street; my father lives in Bond-court, John-street, Commercial-road

On Sunday night, the 12th of September, my mistress gave me leave to go home—I left about eight o'clock, and met my sister Mar
garet and George Lartin, and went with them towards my father's house—just before we got into John-street, I saw the prisoner with his wife and a man and woman, on the other side of the way—the prisoner called after us, and made use of very improper names—he said, "You had better go home to such a house, or you will not be able to get up early enough in the morning"—I said he had better go about his business, and that there was another way to make him pay for what he had said—Lartin went up to him and said, "Are you aware that you are taking these young womens' character away?"—I said to Lartin, "You had better come away, don't have any conversation with him, there is another way to make him prove what he has said, besides having any words with him"—I went up to Lartin to tell him to come away, when the prisoner and his wife struck me both together—the prisoner struck me with his fist on the head, and tore my hair—part of my head is completely bare, and he tore the skirts of my gown off, and tore my collar—my mother came up, and he commenced beat
ing her in the same manner, and tore her hair—I went to my father's, changed my dress, and came to the street-door to go home, and saw a crowd of people outside—as I went down the steps of the door, the prisoner came to the gate of the fore court and threw a stone, and said, "Take that," making use of bad words, and struck me on the forehead—I do not know what happened afterwards—I was taken to the surgeon's—I saw some flower-pots thrown down, but I cannot say who threw them—he threw a brick at me—I had not abused him, or offered him the slightest provo
cation—I was at St. Thomas's Hospital from the 12th of September to the 1st of October.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to state that it was done without the slightest provocation? A. Not the least—I used no violence—I did nothing to the prisoner's wife—I believe Lartin has lived with his friends since the transaction—he has not lived in our family—he has not lived in my mother's house since the transaction—I did not see any of the prisoner's windows smashed—there was nothing whatever done to him by any of the party.
COURT. Q. What is the principal injury you was in the hospital for? A. The blow on the forehead.

GEORGE LARTIN . I am a barge builder, and live in John-street, Com
mercial-road. On Sunday night, the 12th of September, I was coming oat of my father's house in Bond-court, and saw Miss Mahoney and her sister coming along—I spoke to them, and was with them when this oc
curred—I saw the prisoner standing at the end of Bond-street, talking to two females and a young man—I knew him by sight—as we passed he called after the females—he called the prosecutrix a b——w——, telling her to go home to a b——house, and then she could get up early in the morning—I went to him and said, "Don't you know that you are taking these females characters away; you are doing very wrong, it is not only them who hear it, there are people standing at their own doors, and they tear it as well"—he said, "George, we don't want to have any quarrel
ling with you, go about your business"—Miss Mahoney came to me and said, "George, don't talk to them people, we have another way to make them pay for it, without a disturbance in the street"—he directly came round, struck her, tore, her dress off her back, and terribly ill-used her—

her mother came up, and I stopped him from striking her, as he had her against a brick-wall—I pulled him away from her—after that I thought all was quiet—the prosecutrix went into her father's house with her sister and me—in about ten minutes after I thought all was quiet and came outside the door, and saw the prisoner at his up-stairs window throwing flower-pots out—the prosecutrix was just in the door then—he stood with his head out of the window, throwing the pots down on the people below—there must have been twenty people there outside the railing—there were three inside the railing—he threw the pots down into Mr. Mahoney's front yard—I did not speak a word to him—I saw the prosecutrix leaving the house, and when she came outside the door, about ten minutes after the disturbance, the prisoner deliberately came out of his house with a brick in his hand, and stood about six yards from Mahoney's house, in front of the house, said something, and flung the brick at her—it struck her on the head—she was immediately conveyed to Mr. Menzie's—she fell down, a young man named Thorn picked her up, and carried her to the doctor's—her sister fainted—the prisoner afterwards threw a pint pot and hit Mr. Mahoney on the side—he threw nothing else but the flower-pot.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you never represented that he flung a flint stone at her? A. There was a flint stone flung—I believe that he flung it—I have never said that I saw him fling it—I was before the Magistrate—I believe the prisoner was allowed to go on his own recogni
zance—I saw him at large afterwards—I believe one of the women I saw the prisoner with, was his wife—I did not speak a word before it happened—he insulted the women in the street, and I asked him what he had to do with them—I have not been very intimate at Mahoney's house—I have sometimes been there, once or twice a day—I was there three times on Saturday—I have told all that happened—there were no stones or any thing thrown from our yard—I did not see the brick—I used no kind of vio
lence myself—one Bennett was present—I know Jones, a master baker, he might have been at his door at the time this took place—I did not see him nor his shopman, Choun—I know Boddy—I did not see him there—nothing happened to the prisoner's wife in my presence, nor was any violence used to her—I did not see Mrs. Beechey there—I do not know a woman named Parker—I have never spoken to her to my knowledge—I did not see her there, to my knowledge—I do not know Mrs. Austin—I had nothing to do with the violence used, more than pulling the prisoner from Mrs. Mahoney.

MARGARET MAHONEY . I am the prosecutrix's sister, and was in the service of Colonel Douglas. On the Sunday evening I was with my sister and Lartin, going to my father's—I saw the prisoner with his wife, and a man and women on the opposite side of the way—we passed him, and took no notice of him—after we passed him he called us very improper names, telling us to go home, or we should not be able to get up early in the morning—Lartin went up and asked him if he was aware he was taking the young women's characters away—my sister went up and told Lartin to come away, then instantly struck my sister, and tore her dress—after that we went home to my father's house, to change her dress, and after that he hove out the flower-pots—I saw him do it—I was standing at the door—I was obliged to go on one side to get away from the flower-pots—I was going out at the time—there were several people standing round, whom I

did not know—I saw him throw them from his window—my sister was on the step of the door when the prisoner came out in the act of fighting, with a brick in his hand—he hove it at my sister, and said, "Take that," using a bad name, and struck her on the forehead, and she fell.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw nothing happen to the prisoner's wife? A. Not any thing—she was let go quietly along—nobody molested her in the slightest degree—Lartin was by my side when the flint stone was thrown—I saw it quite plain, and saw who threw.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the prisoner throw a flint stone? A. Yes, before the brick was thrown.

JOHN THORN . I live in James-place, near John-street; I am a stranger to all these parties. On the evening in question I was in John-street—I heard the cry of "Murder," and ran to see what was the matter—I saw the prosecutrix and her sister in the fore-court—I stopped some minutes, and saw the prisoner come out of his own house and throw the brick violently—he merely crossed the fore-court, and threw it—he did not aim at either party that I know of—the two sisters were standing together, and it struck the prosecutrix—he threw it towards them—he was five or six yards from them—I did not see him throw any thing else.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever said you saw him coming out and throw a large flint stone before he threw the brick? A. No, I said a brick—I saw a flint—I did not see it thrown—they told me it was thrown—I did not tell that gentleman (Mr. Crisp) that I saw the prisoner throw a large flint stone at the persons in the court.

JOHN SHEREDAN . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into cus
tody, and took him to Union-hall—the prosecutrix was unable to attend—I produce a flint and brick, which I got from Margaret Mahoney.

MARGARET MAHONEY
re-examined. This is the flint stone which was thrown—I gave that and the brick to the officer—I picked them up before my sister was picked up.

JAMES VAUGHAN . I am a surgeon at St. Thomas's Hospital. On Sun
day night, the 12th of September, the prosecutrix was brought there—I examined her head, and found a scalp wound in the forehead, on the right side, extending about an inch or more—it exposed the covering of the bone—she was insensible, and was about three weeks under my care—it was a dangerous wound.
Cross-examined. Q. Dangerous, because it might produce erysipelas, I suppose? A. Yes.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

ANTHONY BENNETT . I have been nine years a labourer in Mr. Watkins's manufactory in the Commercial-road. I was in company with the prisoner, his wife, and another young woman, on the night in question—we were standing at the corner between John-street and Bond-street—Lartin came over and said to Conlon, "What have to say to these young women, my friends?"—Conlon had not at that time said any thing to either of them—he turned round and said, "Nothing"—the prosecutrix came over and swore she would knock the prisoner's wife's brains out—she collared her by the throat, and said she would have her brains out—her mother ran over after her, and Lartin came over—I tried all I could to make peace between them—I took no part in the affray—Lartin came and struck him—I heard a cry of "Murder," ran over to the corner of John-street, and picked the prisoner up.
who was down—Lartin came and said, "D—his eyes, I will have it out of him," and pitched into—him—I saw no more.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the garden-pots thrown? A. No—I did not go down to the place at that time—I did not see the flint and brickbat thrown.

GEORGE JONES . I am master-baker, and live in John-street. On the night in question I was standing at my own door between eight and nine o'clock—I noticed the prisoner, his wife, and two men coming up John-street—when they got opposite my door they stopped talking together—I saw Lartin walk over to them—he said, "What is this you have got to say concerning my friends?"—the prisoner replied, "I do not know your friends, I have no friends but my own here, who I am talking with"—the prosecutrix and her sister advanced towards the prisoner and made use of most dreadful oaths, and said they would tear her liver out—they imme
diately collared her, and had her to the ground—I saw Lartin strike the prisoner—he brought him back some distance and struck him many blows—at last he knocked him down and began to kick him—I saw a young man go in among the few gathered together, and pick him up, and as he picked him up I saw Lartin strike him again in his harness—I have no connexion with the prisoner or his friends—a great crowd of people collected.
MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the prosecutrix's gown torn off? A. No, nor the flower-pots or flint thrown—I did not go off the step of ray door—I did not see either of the Mahoney's struck.

WILLIAM CHOUN . I am journeyman to Mr. Jones. I did not see the commencement of this, but when the prisoner went down the court to his own house I went down with him—he had all his things nearly torn off his back at that time—we had to pass Mahoney's door, and saw three of them—they were stripped to their stays to fight, waiting for the prisoner, and when he came by the door they all three laid hold of him and beat him—Lartin also took him by the neck and hit him three or four times—I did not try to assist the prisoner—I did not know him before—I told Lartin he ought to be ashamed of himself—some man then took hold of the prisoner and took him away, and I took him into his own house myself—the women came hooting to him to come out again, and somebody came and pushed the door—when I came out I met one of them with a stone and a brick in her hand—somebody begged her not to throw it at the window, and she said she would be d—if she would not—I heard the window smash—I could not see who did it.
MR. DOANE. Q. Were you there when the garden-pots were thrown? A. No, nor the flint or brick.

JAMES BODDY . I am a master-carman, and live in Bond-street. On Sunday the 12th of December, between eight and nine o'clock, as I and my wife and family sat in the kitchen we heard violent screaming—my wife went up, and I followed, and my children also—I opened my door and saw two men fighting—I do not know them—there was a cry of "For G—sake let this good woman come in or she will be murdered"—it was the prisoner's wife—I saw her afterwards—she was then being dragged on the curb of the pavement by females, who I did not know, but I have since found one of them to be Bridget Mahoney—I went to lift the prisoners wife and found she was grasped by Bridget Mahoney by her long hair behind—I ungrasped her hand and she was taken away—she was down at the time and her hair was entangled in Mahoney's hand.

——BEACHEY. I am the wife of James Beachey, and live in Bond-stree. On Sunday night the 12th of November I was in my room with my door open, and heard screams of "Murder" and "Police"—I went up and saw the prisoner's wife in the hands of three women, her hair being pulled off her head—I said, "For G—sake some man release the woman"—Mr. Boddy opened his door—I instantly went to the corner of the street and saw the prisoner in the hands of Mrs. Mahoney pulling her face down, and I saw her clasp the prisoner by his whiskers, and he put his hand on her hair and cap to prevent her hitting him—she had him by the side of the face, and her daughter Mary came and struck him—I also saw a strange man come and strike him—I should not know him again—I also saw Lartin strike him in his mouth, and I saw him strike him again and knock him down.

---- PARKER. I am a widow, and live at No. 27, Bond-street. I heard a most dreadful noise between nine and ten o'clock—I went down to see what it was, and saw Miss Mahoney pick up the bricks and throw them into the prisoner's window—they returned again, and as Bridget Mahoney was running into her own house she fell down on the corner of the step, and received a blow—she was afterwards carried to the doctor's—I had seen her smash the prisoner's windows with the bricks she flung.

MR. DOANE. Q. How many brickbats did she throw into the window? A. I do not know how many—I saw more than one thrown by both the sisters—I cannot say what sort of brickbats they were—I saw no garden-pots thrown—I am no friend of the prisoner's nor an enemy of the other party—I saw the prisoner at his own room-window after Bridget Mahoney fell down and was carried to the doctor's—I did not see him come out of his house.
COURT. Q. Give us some notion of the manner in which she fell. A. She was running into her own gate, and fell down and hit her forehead on the right hand side going in doors.

---- AUSTIN. I am the wife of John Austin, a carpenter, in Bond-court. Hearing a most dreadful confusion in the court, I went out, and saw Mary Bridget Mahoney run out of the prisoner's yard on the opposite side, and she fell against the step of her own door—the blood ran very furiously from her forehead—both parties are strangers to me, and I have no interest in coming to speak.
MR. DOANE. Q. When she fell she was carried to the doctor's? A. I went to my own door, and saw her carried away then—when she fell the prisoner was up at the window of his own house—I swear that.

MR. CRISP. I am solicitor to the prosecution. In consequence of there being no depositions taken before the Magistrate, I thought it right to take as accurately as I could from the witnesses what they deposed, and fur-nished the other side with a copy of it—I heard the witness Thorn say that he never told me he saw the prisoner threw a large flint stone at the people—he distinctly told me he saw a flint stone thrown first, and after
wards a brick, by the prisoner.

JAMES VAUGHAN
re-examined. It was a contused wound—it must have been from a stone or something—a fall might account for it, but she must nave fallen very heavily—if she had fallen down her face would most likely have been injured, and it was only injured at the one part on the forehead.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

283.
JEREMIAH DELAY was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of November, 52lbs. weight of lead, value 8s., the goods of
James Easton and another; and
CHARLES MAYHEW
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

WILLIAM TOOGOOD TIMEWELL . I am a clerk in the service of James Easton and another, engineers, wheelwrights, and lead merchants, in the Grove, Great Guildford-street, Borough. This piece of lead, now produced, weighing 52lbs., resembles the lead on my master's premises—it has no particular mark, but it is cast in a particular way—the prisoner Delay was employed as a labouring bricklayer on the premises—he had access to the lead—he was desired to remove it out of the way where they were building a boiler—I found it at a marine store-shop in Redcross-street—I was after
wards with the officer when he took Mayhew in Castle-street—he said he had taken a piece of lead from Delay, and had sold it in Castle-street, that Delay gave it him in the Grove, Great Guildford-street, and that it was handed out at the door of the factory to him.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did Mayhew say he got it from Delay? A. Yes—I have no doubt I told the Magistrate of it—I meant to do so if I did not.

SILAS HARRIS . I am a blacklead merchant, and live at the Grove, Great Guildford-street. On Monday, the 29th of November, I saw a bricklayer's labourer come out of Mr. Easton's gate with something, which he gave to Mayhew, who was waiting at the side—I followed him to Wright's shop in Redcross-street, and saw it weighed—I afterwards fol
lowed Mayhew to his house in Castle-street, and then gave information to the police, and to the prosecutor.

MANY ANN WRIGHT . I am the wife of James Wright, a marine-store dealer. The prisoner Mayhew came to my shop with this lump of lead—he said it was his property—I gave him 1d. a pound for it—that is the price given at our shop for lead—I do not know whether it was new lead—I gave 4s. 4d. for it.

SOLOMON GARNETT . I am a policeman. I went to Redcross-street, and found the lead, and to Castle-street, and found the prisoner Mayhew—I told him I wanted him for stealing a piece of lead out of the Grove—he told me he had a piece from the Grove, that a man had given him, and he had sold it at a shop in Redcross-street.
Cross-examined. Q. Who was with you? A. Mr. Timewell—I asked Mayhew the name of the man who had given it him, and he said be did not know—I did not hear him mention Delay's name.

JAMES TIDMARSH . I am a policeman. I took Delay into custody—he denied all knowledge of it, but in going to the police-court, I told him to carry it—he said, "It is not the first time I have carried it—it dropped from a cart in the Grove, and I gave it to Mayhew to sell for me—he gave me 18d. for my share."
Cross-examined. Q. Who was present at the time? A. Several police-men —he told it to me without my asking.
(Delay received a good character.)

DELAY—
GUILTY . Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

MAYHEW—
NOT GUILTY .

284.
MARY NIBBS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 purse, value 2s., and 15 sovereigns, the property of
Ann Grimmett, in the Dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Beatrice Alsager .
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

ANN GRIMMETT . I was in the service of Mrs. Elizabeth Beatrice Alsager, the widow of Captain Alsager; she lives at Balham-hill, in the parish of Streatham. On the 8th of February the family left town, and I left on the 19th—I left fifteen sovereigns in a small drawer in a chest, in my bed-room, at the top of the house—I locked the drawer and took the key with me—the prisoner had been left in charge of the house, and had Willis, her niece, with her—I returned on the 12th of October, and went to my drawer next morning—I found it still locked, but had a difficulty in getting it open—I found the things in it all turned about, and my money gone—I called the prisoner up, and told her I had been robbed—she said she did not know any thing about it—(she was merely a charwoman left in charge of the house)—I told her the drawer must have been undone, I thought by a key—I asked if there could be any key in the house which would undo the drawer—she then fetched a key, which I tried to the drawer—it un
locked three of them, one of which my money had been in—next morning I noticed marks of a chisel on the drawers all over the house, and on my drawer also—they could be seen without opening the drawer—two chisels were found in the house—the police were called in.

COURT. Q. Before you noticed the marks, had you been all over the house to examine whether they must have been made after you ascertained your own loss? A. No, I did not see the marks till the police found them out—my sight is not good, and I might not observe them if they had been there before.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long has the prisoner's husband lived in the neighbourhood with her? A. Some years—he worked on Mr. Borradale's farm—I do not know whether he was his bailiff—the prisoner was discharged on bail—I think the marks on the drawers were mentioned before she was discharged—we also indicted Willis, and the Grand Jury ignored the bill—I do not know any thing of the prisoner and her husband being known as people of property—I have known her seven or eight years in the neighbourhood—I have not spoken to Willis this morning—the prisoner only brought me one key—she had not two in her hand—I have not brought the drawer here, or the chisels—she went for the key directly I told her to fetch what she had—I lost a purse, which I have not found—there was no other charge against her.

SAMUEL LONGBOTTOM (police-constable V 10.) I took the prisoner in charge on Monday, the 18th of November, and went to her lodgings the same day, in the Balham-road, rather better than a quarter of a mile from Mrs. Alsager's—I found her husband there, and in a box under their bed I found from 400l. to 500l. in one bag, and about 100l. in another bag, in gold and silver—the 100l. was in a black stocking—I found under the same bed a tea-caddy, which I produce, with two purses in it, one con
tained about 9l. or 10l. in gold, silver, and copper—there were two or three farthings, and separate from the purses, not wrapped in any thing, I found fifteen sovereigns loose in the bottom, where the sugar basin would be—a purse, with money in it, laid over it—her husband was present when the money and caddy was found, but not when the caddy was broken open—
it was locked, and brought away locked as it was—I opened it when I got home—I have not the key of it.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was in custody, did you ask her for the key of the caddy? A. No, she was in Horsemonger-lane, I had no opportunity—I enquired about it, and I was told not—Busain, my inspector, told me I could not see her—I asked him if I was to apply to the Magis
trate, and he said it was best not—only my wife was present when I broke it open—I took the niece in charge—I have not brought the drawer here—the inspector did not tell me not to bring it—the marks were very visible—when the drawer was open you could see where the chisel had been—there are no marks outside—I have never seen the key the pri
soner produced—the chisels are Mrs. Alsager's—I have known the prisoner and her husband about the place for four years myself—I cannot say whether they are much respected, nor whether it was neces
sary to bespeak the prisoner's services three weeks before they could he had.
MR. BODKIN. Q. How long had she been in custody when you found the caddy? A. One day—she was searched when she was taken—I was not in the room.
HANNAH WILLIS . I am the prisoner's niece, and was with her at Mrs. Alsager's, when the family left town. The tea-caddy belongs to me—I lent it to the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you got the key now? A. No, my aunt has it—she has lived eighteen years where she does now—my uncle is about fifty years old—I know he lent some money to a gentleman named Brand—I was taken into custody on this charge by the officer—I was not in the house when my aunt was apprehended—I had been in the house with her nearly all the time—she never had the charge of a house before—she went out to work for gentlemen and ladies in the neighbourhood—they have been obliged to wait a long time for her at times, she was so en
gaged.

COURT. Q. Did you know any thing of two chisels in the house? A. I never saw them—I saw the key, which was left in a drawer for my aunt to put her things into—when the cook came home, she went to her drawer next morning, then called my aunt up, and said she had left fifteen sover
eigns in her drawer, which were gone, and asked if there was any key in the house which would open it—my aunt gave her what keys she had, and among them was the key of the caddy—the keys were all returned to my aunt.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know which key opened the drawer in question? A. The one that had been left in the drawer when they left—the footman was at the house for three months after Mrs. Alsagar left—he had one gentleman come once and slept in the same bed with him—there was a Jew came twice—he did not sleep there.

DAVID M'LEAN . I was footman to Mrs. Alsager, and remained in the house up to the 30th of June. After she left, my uncle, who is seventy-three years old, came to see me one Saturday night, slept there, and went away on Sunday—he lives at Poplar, and is a ship-carpenter—a Jew came twice I believe—he was in the habit of buying old liveries of the servants, and he did buy some—I slept in the front room, the best room, to protect the house.
Cross-examined. Q. Did your uncle walk from the house? A. Yes, and I went with him as far as Clapham—I cannot tell where the Jew lives.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Was the Jew taken up stairs? A. No, he was not beyond the lobby—I have seen him since at Clapham, but not to speak to him—he is always to be found—there were chisels in a drawer in the library, with other tools, belonging to the late captain—that drawer was always open—I have not been up stairs to examine the marks on the drawer—I was never up stairs after the 30th of June—the prosecutrix occupied the garret, and the prisoner the adjoining room.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was she permitted to go out in the day time, al
though in charge of the house? A. She was to go out occasionally—she told Mrs. Alsager that it might be about three days a week—she always slept there, except for three days, when she went to see her father, or to bury him.

SAMUEL LONGBOTTOM
re-examined. I saw the chisels fitted to the marks on the drawers—they appeared to have been made by the chisels—I mentioned this to Mr. Painter the Magistrate.

MRS. GRIMMETT (looking at the fifteen sovereigns.) Here is one which is the colour of one of mine—I cannot say any thing about the others—I had noticed two of my sovereigns being of the present Queen's reign, and there are only two among them of this reign—one was a brighter colour than the other, and here is a little difference in the colour of one of these.
Cross-examined. Q. Had one of them, to the best of your judgment, never been in circulation? A. Yes, Captain Alsager had brought some new sovereigns home from the Bank, and mistress gave me one.
SAMUEL LONGBOTTOM . Directly I found the sovereigns I looked over them, having been told there were two particular ones—the rest are all of the reign of George IV., except one, which is William.

HANNAH WILLIS
re-examined. When my aunt borrowed the caddy of me it used to stand on the top of a bed in a front room at her house—she bor
rowed it when I first took it home, two years ago, and had the use of it all along, and. the key—it was in her exclusive possession—I had not the key at all.

MRS. GRIMMET re-examined. I received thirteen of the sovereigns last Christmas—I have had one of the sovereigns by me some years—I kept them altogether in my drawer, not in my pocket, so that they could not get soiled.

HANNAH WILLIS
re-examined. The key of the drawer my aunt used was in the servant's room, which my aunt slept in, next to the cook's room—it was left in the drawer, so that any one could get at it for three months, but after the footman left my aunt locked the drawer, and took the key with her, and as she cleaned all the rooms she locked them, and took the keys.
NOT GUILTY .

285.
JANE THURSTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of No
vember, 5 sovereigns, 1 20l. Bank-note, and 1 5l. Bank-note, the monies of
James Turner, in the dwelling-house of
Ann Colbert.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

JANE TURNER . I am the wife of James Turner. On the 28th of Oc
tober we were lodging at No. 6, Chester-place, Borough-road, which is kept by the prisoner's mother, Ann Colbert—I had the misfortune to put

my knee out on that day—I had a 5l. note, along with other monies, which I placed in a canvas bag in a drawer up stairs, which I locked—in conse
quence of hurting my knee I lived for some time in the room of the pri
