soner's mother—on the 6th of November I gave the prisoner the keys of the drawer up stairs, to bring me down my canvas bag which the money was in—she took the keys, and went up stairs—her mother brought the bag down, and said, "Here is the bag with the money, take care of it"—she introduced a carpet-bag with a padlock and key, and said, "Here is a bag, put the money in it, and lock it up," which I did, and it was put into the cupboard—I did not look at my money before I did so—I remained in that room till the 14th of November—I then opened the bag, and missed a 20l. note, 5l. note, and five sovereigns—I have since seen the 5l. note—I know it by the number and date—I had put it down when I took it from Glynn's banking-house, on the 17th of September—I did not write any thing on it—I did not take the number of the 20l. note—I did not have that from there.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. How many persons have you ac
cused of stealing this money? A. No one but the prisoner and her mother—we did not accuse them, we gave them in charge—we laid an information of our loss at the police-office, and they advised us not to take either of them till we made inquiry—I gave evidence against them both before the Magistrate—the mother was discharged on the third hearing—they were out on bail between the examinations—I mean to swear that I never ac
cused any third person of having improperly had this money—I was mar
ried on the 28th of February last, at St. Sepulchre's church—my husband and I have not lived on very bad terms with respect to this money—it was money which came to me in my own right—I always had it in my own possession—I never charged my husband with endeavouring to get hold of it against my will—I swear that—I had counted my money on the 31st of October—I had eleven 5l. notes altogether in this bag, and one 20l. note—I have a memorandum of the numbers of the notes, which I wrote when I took them from the banker's—I wrote it on the 29th of October—I received them on the 17th of September—I counted my money on the 29th of October, and on the 31st it was safe in the bag—I counted it all over on the 31st, and it was all safe—the 29th was the day after we went into the prisoner's mo
ther's house—I had no particular reason for counting it then—I went to my drawer, and saw it safe in the bag—I have the numbers and dates of all the 5l. notes; at least my husband has—I had not paid any of the 5l. notes away before I discovered my loss—from the 17th of September till the 31st of October I had not paid any away—I was never out of the house—we had taken the Axe public-house in Milton-street, and all the money was paid away then except the note the prisoner stole.
Q. You said this moment you had not paid away any? A. Not of that money—there was none of the eleven 5l. notes or the 20l. note paid away.

COURT. Q. Do you mean that you had eleven 5l. notes and one 20l. note on the 31st of October? A. Yes—when we took the money from the banker's we took the Axe public-house, and paid away all that money except this 5l. note—on the 28th of October we let the house, and received 160l. in notes; but this 5l. note that was lost was the only one remaining out of 224l. 1s. 3d. which I received from Glynn's on the 17th of Sep-tember—24l. of it was in gold; one 100l. note; two 30l.; five 10l.; and five 5l.

MR. RYLAND. Q. Had you any money by you at the time you re
ceived the money from Glynn's? A. Not any—I paid away the whole of that money when we took the Axe, except one 5l. note—on the 28th of October we let the house, and were paid 170l. in Bank of England notes—I did not take the numbers and dates of those notes—there was one 20l., three 10l., ten 5l., and 16l. in cash; therefore I had then eleven 5l. notes altogether, including the one in question—when I counted the money in the bag on the 29th of October, there was 160l. in it, consisting of one 20l., three 10l., eleven 5l. notes, and about 50l. in gold; and I had about 5l. in my pocket—I have lost about 30l.; a 5l. note, a 10l. note, and five sovereigns.

COURT. Q. How can you tell that the note in question was not one of those you paid away? A. This was the only 5l. note I had in my possession of those I received from Glynn's—I paid all the others away—I am certain this was the note I retained—after I had paid away the other 5l. notes, I looked at the one remaining, so as to know the number of it—I swear that—I took the number of this note the day before I left the Axe—it was the only note I then had in my possession, and it was in my purse—here is the memorandum I made—the note is dated July 13th, 1841, and No. 64319—I wrote that on the 27th of October, the day before I left the Axe.

MR. RYLAND. Q. What was your reason for making that memoran
dum, when you had only one 5l. note left? A. Because I should know it was my note—my husband took the other notes from Mr. Brown, who took the Axe of us—after we went to the prisoner's mother's house on the 28th of October, we put the money altogether—my husband had not ac
cess to the bag—he never saw the money after he gave it to me—I never told any body the number of this 5l. note, till it was shown to me—I stopped it at the Bank—I went with my husband to do so, on the 18th or 19th, I think—I do not know whether or not my husband took the paper with him—I told them the number and date, and they stopped it—I do not think I produced the paper—I think I stated the number and date from memory—I believe the prisoner's mother takes in washing, and does what she can for her livelihood—I believe it is a respectable house—I do not know—I knew the prisoner a year and a half ago—she used to do needlework for me—she goes out to needlework and dress-making—she made me two dresses at home once, and also came to my house to work; and in September they went to live at this house, and she wrote me a note, saying they had apartments to let, and would be happy to accommodate us—she did no millinery at home, while I lodged there, nor did she go out—she did nothing at all while I was there—her mother took in a little washing, and there were other lodgers in the house—there was a lady, her daughter, and son, in the first floor; a Mrs. Holt, her daughter, and niece, and a little girl.

Q. Now, there being all those persons in the house, do you mean to assert that you and your husband have not quarrelled about his getting possession wrongfully of this money? A. No, not about the money—I do not know whether there was a looking-glass smashed one day—I be
lieve there was—my husband smashed it—we were quarrelling then—it was not because I charged him with attempting to break open the drawer where the money was, to get possession of it—(looking at a chisel)—I
never saw such a thing as that in my husband's possession—Mrs. Colbert used it to flute her caps.

Q. What were you quarrelling about when the glass was smashed? A. He wanted to go out, and wanted me to give him a few shillings, and I would not—I am forty-three years old, and he is twenty-three—I am po
sitive I never charged him with attempting to break open the drawer, and take the money—nor ever quarrelled with him about it in the hearing of the lodgers—we have had words the same as man and wife would have—when I counted my money on the 14th of November, I missed 30l—not more—80l. in notes, and 38l. in gold, was left—that would make 148l. in all.
Q. I thought you said just now that from the time you counted it on the 31st of October till you missed this none had been taken out, is that so? A. Yes.

COURT. Q. You said you had 160l. how do you account for the dif
ference? A. When we went to the house we paid 9l. or 10l. away in bills, which I can produce—that was out of the 160l. I had no other money—I say when I counted my money on the 29th of October there was 160l., and there was the same when I counted it again on the 31st—it was after that I paid some away.

MR. RYLAND. Q. Have you not stated that between the 31st of October and the 14th of November you had never been to the bag at all? A. I bad not been to the bag at all, only in the presence of the prisoner's mother—I was never out of the room—no money had been taken out of the bag between the 31st of October and the 14th of November—on the Tuesday after I met with the accident I gave my husband five sovereigns to pay for painting the bar, a sovereign to buy him a pair of boots, and a sovereign to pay for moving the goods—I had some medicine for myself, and a lotion for my knee, and a bit of calico, and 1 paid the prisoner's mother 1l. 4s. for rent—I calculate that I spent about 10l. altogether for every thing—that 10l. was part of the 160l., and came out of the bag after the 31st of October, and after the 6th of November—I did not count my money on the 6th of November—my hus
band was at home at the time I sent the prisoner up stairs for the money.

Q. Why not send him to fetch it? A. He was not in the room at the time—he was up stairs in the room where the money was—I was in bed, and not able to go up stairs myself, and I asked the prisoner as a favour to go and get it for me—I did not think it necessary to ask her to give my husband the key to get it—I placed implicit confidence in her: not more I think than I did in him—I sent for it because I wanted some money, and when the prisoner's mother brought it down I took out half-a-sovereign—I did not count the remainder.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was anybody ever present when you counted your money? A. The prisoner and her mother were on the morning of the 29th of October—I counted it in the parlour before them—between the 6th and the 14th of November I went to the bag and took a half-sovereign out, but did not count the money—I did not disturb it.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to say that during the whole time your hus
band never had access to your money-bag? A. No, what I thought proper he should have I gave him—I had the keys of the drawer where it was, in my possession—I always kept the key about me, and when I went to bed I put it in my pocket under my head.

JAMES TURNER (examined by MR. RYLAND.) I am twenty-three years of age—I have been married to the last witness nine months—I first heard of the loss of the money on the 14th of November—I knew very little about the money myself—my wife was very careful of it indeed—we had very little squabbling about it—she never charged me with stealing it—I swear that—I have seen some of the lodgers here—my wife never complained that I tried to break open the drawer where the money was, and take it away against her will—I did break open a drawer—I did not expect to find the money there—I broke it open to aggravate her—the money was gone—I did not know the money was in the drawer that I broke open—I expected it was—I did not break it open for the purpose of taking the money—if I had found it there I intended to have taken it to her for her to give me some out of it—I smashed a glass one day—it was my own property—I had not been quarrelling with my wife about the money—we had had a few words and I revenged myself on the glass—I never told the lodgers when the money was missed that I had got it, and if it was all right I would have a flare
up, and if the old girl behaved herself well I would give her back part of it, nor anything of the sort—I deny the whole of it—I did not say the money was all right, and I had got it—I never did take any of it against her will, nor with her will—I helped to count it on the 14th of November—there was ten 5l. notes, three 10l. notes, and 37l. in gold—I had never seen it counted before.

EDWARD M'KEANE . I am clerk at Messrs. Glynn's bank. I know the prosecutrix—I cannot say that I saw her on the 17th of September last—I have an extract from our book here, not the book itself—I made the extract last Thursday—I made the original entry in the book, and made the extract from the original entry.
COURT. Q. Have you refreshed your memory by the original entry to-day? A. Not to-day—I have a recollection of the note in question from my reference to the entry the other day, I bore it in mind.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you look at the book? A. Last Thursday, when I made the extract—I am quite certain the two agree—I compared them with particular care that there should be no mistake—there is never more than one note of the same amount, number, and date in cir
culation—that is a rule at the Bank.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Can you tell whether you paid away any 5l. note on the 17th of September? A. I paid away several—the memorandum I have is a list of the notes I paid away—here is one 5l. note, No. 64319, dated 13th July, 1841.

MARTHA NICHOLLS . I am the wife of John Nicholls, a baker, in Union-street. I have known the prisoner about two months, and may have seen her a dozen or twenty times—I know her person quite well—she has dealt at our house for bread—I received a 5l. note from her.

Q. Should you know it again; did you put any writing on it? A. I put writing on a 5l. note—I do not remember whether I wrote on the note I received from her at the time or not—the note that was produced to me had my handwriting on it—I have been examined before—I know the prisoner as a customer—I remember her coming and asking me for change for a 5l. note—I do not recollect whether or not I wrote any thing on it at that time—I saw my handwriting on the note which was pro
duced before the Magistrate, but I do not know when I wrote it—I did
not know my writing was on it till I saw it—I must, no doubt, have put it on a short time after I received it—perhaps five or ten minutes after.

Q. Are you sure it was the same note you received from her that yon put the writing on? A. I took no other—I had, no doubt, other 5l. notes at the time, up in my bed-room—I took the note I got from her to the rest—I always write on them before I put them away, but I might possibly have left it till the evening, till I went to bed—I wrote on the note—I do not know how soon after I received it—perhaps ten minutes—I am sure I wrote on it before I put it among the other notes—I wrote on it "No. 6, Borough-road "—I did not know her name, so I put the resi
dence—I knew where she lived by our leaving the bread.

COURT. Q. Are you sure it was on the note you received from the pri
soner, that you wrote "6, Borough-road?" A. I—really cannot say, to be sure—I am not sure it was on that note.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What other note was there for you to put it on? A. I had no other to put it on.

COURT. Q. Do you speak to it from finding your writing on it, or do you recollect putting, "6, Borough-road" on it? A. I do not recollect writing it, certainly—I always write on them as soon as I have them—I know I wrote, "6, Borough-road" on a note—I changed her a 5l. note, and the note produced has my writing on it—that is all I know about it—I cannot positively say this is the note I received from the prisoner—I did not write "6, Borough-road" by mistake upon a note which I did not receive from the prisoner—I only received one note from the prisoner—I have no recollection of writing this on the note.
MR. PHILLIPS declined proceeding further with the Prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

286.
JAMES WALTER JONES was indicted
for feloniously receiving of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 4th of November, 11 yards of velvet, value 14l., the goods of
James Dickons Saltmer, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

RICHARD EVANS . I am warehouseman, in the employ of Mr. Saltmer, of Friday-street, Cheapside—the witness, M'Knight, was taken into cus
tody, and made a statement. On the 19th of November I went to the prisoner's shop, No. 2, Cumberland-row, Newington-butts, accompanied by M'Knight and Mr. M'Lean—it is a second-hand clothes' shop—I and Mr. Knight went into the shop together—I had a parcel—the prisoner was at home, and an elderly man sat by the fire-side with him, who immediately went out—he was lame, and walked with a stick—on M'Knight seeing the prisoner, he said, "That is the man I sold the goods to"—to the best of my belief those were his words—I called M'Lean in, who said to the prisoner, "I must have these goods"—the prisoner said, "Oh, what I bought of this young man?"—M'Lean said, "Yes"—the prisoner said, "The twelve lengths"—he said he did not know the value of them when I told him, and said he had bought the twelve lengths for 9s., he said he did not know what a velvet was, that he never had a silk velvet in his shop, and did not know the value of it at all—he began to cry—he said he had sold them to a stranger, and if the inspector

would allow him to go, he might he able to find that stranger, but he could not without—the inspector said, no, he must go with him—he asked the inspector if he would go with him to his master's shop, and they went out together—the prisoner had no hat on—I stopped at the shop—they were gone about ten minutes—they came back to the shop—the prisoner was crying very much—he said he did not know the value of them—we came away in a cab with him—his house was searched, but nothing was found—he was taken to the station, and there he said he only had six lengths—when M'Knight made the statement to me at my master's warehouse, he pointed to some patterns of velvets in our books—I have ascertained that velvets of that pattern are missing to a much larger extent than M'Knight acknowledges—a waistcoat-length is 7/8, where he says he has only cut 3/4, I miss three or four yards—the velvets he pointed out are of different patterns, some worth about 325. a yard, some less, none under 24s.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Repeat what passed between you and the prisoner when you were in the shop with M'Knight? A. M'Lean said he must have these goods—the prisoner said, "You mean the goods I bought of this young man?"—I said, "Yes, what have you done with them?"—he said, "I have sold them, I am not obliged to keep them"—I said, "To whom did you sell them?"—he said, "To a stranger, if you will allow me to go perhaps I can find him"—we said, "Perhaps you can give his address?"—he said "No, it is somewhere in the City."
COURT. Q. Then the word "goods" was mentioned throughout in the conversation? A. Lengths they were called—I called them twelve lengths—the prisoner said "remnants."
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know whether pieces of velvet are cut up for stocks? A. Very few—I have never seen them.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Were the words, "twelve lengths," used by any body in the prisoner's presence? A. By me—when he said they were remnants, I said they were twelve lengths for waistcoats—he said they would not make boys' waistcoats.

FRANCIS M'LEAN . I accompanied Evans and M'Knight to the prisoner's shop at Newington—Evans and M'Knight went in first—they afterwards called me in—I asked the prisoner where the twelve cuts were—Evans and him were talking—he said he had sold them to a stranger for 2s. profit—he also said he was a poor young man, and that was his shop—I searched the shop, but found nothing—I said he must go with me—he said he thought if I would let him go he could find out the person he had sold them to—he began crying two or three times, and said, "Will you go down with me to the other shop?"—I accompanied him there—it was about a hundred yards—he was crying almost all the way—when I got there I found it was Mr. Davis's shop, who it appeared was his employer—I asked Davis if he knew any thing about the sale of them—he said he did not know any thing about them—some conversation passed, but it was just at the Sabbath, and they begged me to let him go back to shut up the shop, which I did—I made no search at Davis's—I took the prisoner to the station, and there he said he had not bought more than six cuts—he acknowledged to the twelve at the shop—he said he gave 9s. for them.

JAMES DICKONS SALTMER . The value of the twelve lengths of goods pointed out by M'Knight would be 5l., if cut into twelve waistcoat lengths—I should certainly say such articles are not used for velvet neckcloths—I have seen velvet neckcloths, but never any of that sort.

BENJAMIN M'KNIGHT (a Prisoner. See page 198.) I was in the prose
cutor's employ—I took twelve lengths of velvet from his premises—eleven were sufficient for a waistcoat, and the twelfth for two—I afterwards pointed out to Evans some of the patterns which I took—I first saw the prisoner one Saturday night, about three weeks ago, at his shop at Newington Causeway—I had nothing with me then—I asked him if he would buy some length of figured velvet for waistcoats—he said, "Yes"—I went again on the Mon
day, I believe, and took the twelve lengths which I have mentioned with me—I got there about half-past eight o'clock in the evening—I found him there—there was a boy present in the shop—he was bringing in some waistcoats as they were going to shut up—he went out and came in again—I opened the parcel—the prisoner asked what I wanted for them—I did not mention any price, but he said he would give me 9s. for the lot—he said nothing more—I said, "Would he give more than that, it was not enough for them"—he said no, he was a man to his word—he said nothing else—I took the 9s. which he paid me.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it true that your master and Cuthbert gave you two hours before you made your statement, after they told you they would prosecute you, if you did not tell what you knew? A. I do not think it was quite two hours.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did any body tell you you should be prosecuted if you did not tell this story? A. Yes, Mr. Cuthbert—he told me it would be much better to confess every thing, that Mr. Saltmer did not wish to hurt me at all—that was on the occasion when I was given two hours to consider what I had to say.

COURT. Q. Is it true you were threatened to be prosecuted if you did not tell this story? A. Not in those words—I do not remember its being said that I should be prosecuted unless I did tell—Mr. Saltmer told me to confess every thing, and that he did not wish to hurt me—that is all I re
member he said I was likely to be prosecuted if I did not—I told him this transation—it was not suggested that I was to be made a witness of.

JAMES CUTHBERT . I was a ward-constable; I have resigned that office. I was called to Mr. Saltmer's before M'Knight was taken into custody—I saw him—I should wish to remark that I had some conversation with Mr. Saltmer before I saw the lad—I should not have acted upon that, had I not been deceived by Mr. Saltmer—I should not have lent myself to any thing—Evans came to me when I was at home and said, "We have another job at our house"—I said, "Well, you had better have an officer, for if it is a prosecution I shall have nothing to do with it, as I have resigned office"—he said, "Oh, it is only just to frighten that lad of ours"—I went and saw Mr. Saltmer, and had some conversation with him—he said it was merely to know to what extent, and he would start him—I went into the cellar where the lad was, and said to him, "This is a sad affair"— he said, "Yes, it is"—I said, "Well, Mr. Saltmer has every reason to believe you have taken more goods than what you say"—he said, "No, I have not"—I said, "I am confident Mr. Saltmer is of opinion that you have, and if he would not prosecute you, would you tell all you have taken"—he directly turned round and said, "Has he said so?"—I said, "I will call him down, and he shall say so"—I left Evans and him together in conversation, and called Mr. Saltmer down—there was some conversation, and Mr. Saltmer said he had made no promise—I then walked away to the other end.

Cross-examined. Q. Would you have lent yourself to this frightening the boy by the threat of a prosecution if you had not been induced to do so by what Evans said? A. Certainly not—I should have thought it wrong to do so.

J. D. SALTMER re-examined. Q. Will you explain under what circum
stances M'Knight made the statement? A. I was a great deal engaged at the time in business, and was desirous of ascertaining all I thought he had taken—I sent for an officer—Cuthbert was brought—I said, "This youth has been robbing me, and perhaps you can get from him better than I can the ex
tent of his depredations"—I certainly did not authorise him to hold out to the lad, that if he told the truth he would not be prosecuted—I did not tell Cuthbert that I did not wish to hurt him at all, and that it would be better to confess the whole—it never was my intention not to prosecute the lad, and when Cuthbert said, down stairs, "If you will promise not to pro
secute him he will confess to all he has done"—I said, "I will make him no promise, but give him pencil and paper, and let him write down all he has taken."
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

287.
RICHARD HITCHMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of November, 1 purse, value 1s.; 10 shillings, and 2 sixpences; the pro
perty of
Joseph Limperani, from the person of
Christiana Judith Limperani.

CHRISTIANA JUDITH LIMPERANI . I am the wife of Joseph Limperani; we live in Albany-road, Camberwell. On the 12th of November, at five o'clock in the afternoon, I was going home with my daughter from Walworth-gate —I got to the corner of Albany-road, between the wall and the Watch-box, exactly at the angle of the road, I felt the proximity of three young men who had been following us—I felt myself touched, and one of the men immediately passed me—seeing him put his left-hand into his pocket, and connecting that with having been touched, I put my own hand into my pocket, and immediately missed my purse—I saw a man pass me who I thought had put his hand into my pocket—I told my daugh
ter I had been robbed, and my purse was gone—a policeman being in the immediate vicinity I gave information immediately—the man who passed me, and put his hand into his pocket had on a brown Taglioni coat, with pockets in front—I lost a purse containing, as nearly as I can recollect, 11s.—next morning the prisoner was produced to me—from his personal appearance he bears a resemblance to one of the three men who were there—I did not turn my head to look in his face—I had got change from Mr. Townsend, and one of the shillings was excessively black between the head and the rim—I have since seen one which I believe to be that—to the best of my belief this is it—(looking at a shilling)—the purse has not been found—this shilling is the only one I can identify.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe it was the shadows of the men you saw? A. I saw the men sideways, by a side glance—I cer
tainly did not see them from top to toe—as I turned my head I saw two heads on one side, and one on the other—I did not see their faces suffi
ciently to identify them—my money was in a green purse.

EDWARD TOWNSEND . I am a wine-merchant, and live in the Walworth-road. On the afternoon of the 12th of November Mrs. Limperani came to my shop—I gave her 9s. 6d. in change of a sovereign—I noticed one

shilling was particularly black—this one (looking at one) resembles it-——when the policeman produced all the money I recognized two shillings, this black one and this other—this has very much the appearance of a bad one on the arms side—I had taken it of a girl but a few minutes before.

MARIANA LIMPERANI . I was walking with my mother that evening—I perfectly recollect three persons being about us—I identify the prisoner as being one of them—I have not any doubt about it—we met them first —they then turned back and walked immediately behind us—I turned then and looked at them a second time, and after my mamma had disco
vered the robbery I saw the prisoner at the corner for a moment, but he turned away—I did not see him again till he was in custody—I have not any doubt that be is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. This was about five o'clock? A. Yes—it was a light afternoon—I had noticed the three men—I have always been equally positive that the prisoner was one of the men I saw—this is my handwriting to this deposition.
Q. Did you not say, "To the best of my belief the prisoner was one of those persons?" A. Yes; I only swore to the best of my belief, and so I do now.
COURT. Q. You have said to-day, "I am sure he is the man;" do you mean to the best of your belief? A. Yes, of course.

THOMAS BALES (police-constable P 191.) On the evening of the 12th of November I saw the prisoner at the corner of the Albany-road—I knew him—I afterwards received information from the prosecutrix, and went in the direction she pointed out—I met the prisoner—I asked if he knew any thing about a purse—he said, "No, what purse?"—I took him to the station—he pulled out of his left-hand pocket ten shillings and two six-pences, and he said that was all he had got—the two shillings now pro
duced are part of what he produced.

JURY. Q. How long elapsed between the prosecutrix speaking to you and your finding the prisoner? A. About five minutes—he had got about a quarter of a mile from the place—I looked over the road, but did not see the purse.

GUILTY .† Aged 25.—
Transported for Ten Years.

288.
ROBERT OLIVER was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

289.
MARY NOY was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of November, 3 sovereigns, 4 half-sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, 2 sixpences, and 15 groats; the monies of
Charles Beck, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

290.
WILLIAM WALLER,
ANN GIFFIN , and
MARY DAVIS , were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October, 9 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, and 6 shillings; the monies of
James William Kenning, from his person; and that Giffin had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES WILLIAM KENNING . I am a dealer in poultry, living in Nep
tune-street, Rotherhithe. About six o'clock, on the 8th of October, I

went to the Black Bull public-house, in Rotherhithe—Waller came in—I drank with him—I was tipsy at the time—before I was tipsy I had ten sovereigns, which I got from my brother—I changed one of them, and had half-a-sovereign and some silver—I did not go to sleep at the Black Bull—this is my handwriting—(looking at his deposition)—I told the Magi
strate I fell asleep in that house—I did not read this—I signed it—it was a misunderstanding—it was at the Victoria I went to sleep.

GEORGE WOOD . I am pot-boy at the Neptune public-house now, but I was pot-boy at the Victoria, on the night of the 28th, when the prosecutor and Waller came there—the prosecutor was drunk—they sat down by the win
dow—I afterwards saw Davis on one side of the prosecutor, and Waller on the other—Giffin was standing before him—they were drinking together—the bell rang for me, and I went to get change for 1s. for my master—when I came back, Waller offered me 1s.—I saw Davis take the prosecu
tor's head on her lap, and Waller and Davis spoke over his back—I went out, and returned in five minutes—Davis and Giffin were then gone out-Waller offered me 1s.—I wanted to know what it was for—he said, "Put it in your pocket"—I took it in my hand, and said, "I don't want it"—I gave it him back again—then Giffin and Davis came in again—Giffin used bad language, and said, "We have only got two or three shillings"—Waller had not said any thing to her—they all bid me good night, and went out; and while I was telling my mistress what they had offered me, all three came in again—I took my supper in the tap-room—Davis and Giffin went into the yard, and Waller went across to where the prosecutor was sitting, he put his hand into his pocket—he then came to me again, and offered me half-a-sovereign, and said, "Put this in your cly"—I said I did not want it—he had got half-a-crown, one shilling, and three halfpence—when he offered me the shilling he said he had only got two or three shillings—he asked me if I had seen anything—I said "No"—he said, "Oh, I thought you saw it all"—Giffin said, "I have only got two or three shillings out of him."

Giffin. You do not tell what you drank yourself out of the liquor the man paid for. Witness. Giffin said she should meet me on the next night, and give me 1s.—I said I should not want her money—Davis did not offer me any thing—Giffin offered me something to drink—I said I did not like it, but I did take a drop after a while—I did not see the prosecutor sober at all—while they were talking in the tap-room they all three ran out the back way—my mistress went out the front way, and brought Giffin and Davis back—(Waller went away)—they came into the tap-room, and asked me to lift the gentleman up, and said he was their friend, they would take him away with them—Davis said that as well as Giffin—I did so—my mistress said, "We had better have a policeman in," and while she was saying that they both ran out the back way again—my mistress went to the door, called a policeman, and told him—he went by the top of the alley, and let them come out and run away—he ran after them, came back, and said he could not catch them—I am sure I saw Waller's hand in the prosecutor's pocket—I did not see what he took out.

JAMES MELLISH (police-constable M 222.) I took Davis—she said she did lot rob the man; but she was certainly in company with Giffin and Waller, and they offered the pot-boy money—I did not see the prosecutor till next morning—he said he had ten sovereigns at the Bull public-house, and had
changed one, and had nine sovereigns, half-a-sovereign, and some silver—he did not say where he got this money from.

Davis's Defence. They asked me to have something to drink—I went in with them—we had a pint of gin and cloves—then he said he had no money—he took 2s. out of his pocket—there was 4d. change—he spent that in biscuits—that was all I saw of his money.
Waller's Defence. It does not look likely that I should go back to the house if I had been guilty—the prosecutor was as sober as I am—he was in other company at the Black Bull public-house.
Giffin. And so he was when he went with us two girls—I offered the Pot-boy no money.
JAMES MELLISH . I produce a certificate of Giffin's former conviction, which I got from the office of the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

WALLER—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

GIFFIN—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Ten Years.

DAVIS—
NOT GUILTY .

291.
ALBERT NORMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of October, 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shirt, value 4s.; 1 waistcoat, value 12s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 12s.; 1 pair of boots, value 15s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 12s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 3s.; 1 hat, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Bigden; and 1 coat, value 6s.; the goods
Abraham Andrews; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month.

292.
MARY ANN WYATT was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of November, 7 wine-glasses, value 4s.; 3 custard cups, value 1s.; 1 tum
bler, value 1s.; 1 salt-cellar, value 1s.; 3 decanters, value 5s.; 1 scent-bottle, value 4s.; 1 bird's bath, value 2s.; 1 bottle, value 6d.; 1 brush, value 6d.; 20 yards of ribbon, value 2s.; 1 bonnet-lining, value 2s.; 3/4 of a yard of woollen cloth, value 2s.; 3 yards of velvet ribbon, value 18s.; 1 apron, value 3d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 9d.; 1 towel, value 8d.; 6 printed books, value 2s.; 1 cloak-lining, value 1s. 6d.; 1 cloak-collar, value 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 book of pictures, value 2d.; the goods of
Gabriel Riddle, her master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Judgment Respited.

293.
MARY ANN WYATT was again indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of October, 1 glass cruet, value 5s.; 6 knives, value 1s. 6d.; 6 forks, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 pair of socks, value 6d.; 4 printed books, value 1s. 6d.; 1 salt-cellar, value 1s.; 1 coffee-pot, value 2s.; 1 mustard-pot, value 6d.; 1 mug, value 6d.; 2 wine-glasses, value 1s.; and 1 cup, value 1s.; the goods of
Gabriel Riddle, her master; and
SARAH PARKER
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the statute, &c.—3rd COUNT, for receiving of a certain evil-disposed person; to which

WYATT pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Judgment Respited.
MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution.
GABRIEL RIDDLE . I am a manufacturer, living in Black friars-road.

Wyatt was my servant on the 2nd of November—on that day I saw Parker in my house—in consequence of something which occurred, I went to a house in Redcross-court, which Parker represented as her house, with two police-officers, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening—we passed through a passage into a back room where Parker was—we looked round, and did not see any thing belonging to me, or where any thing could be secreted—she then led the way to the wash-house behind, where there were two or three women—we looked round, and found nothing there—an officer said it was her sleeping-room—we wanted to know where any property was likely to be that belonged to me—she said it was up stairs—one of the washerwomen then said, "You must not go there, my husband is there"—Parker said she was not going to that room, it was another room—we went up to the top room, second floor, we found nothing there—we were examining the boxes, but the washerwomen came up, and were very angry that their room was being searched—in the mean time Parker had got down stairs again—we came down—she went to the front-room on the ground-floor—we searched in that room—Parker was in the room—and we found the articles stated in the indictment, which be
long to me.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Was the husband in the room when you went? A. Yes—the value of the articles is 18s. or 19s.—these stock
ings have the mark of "L. Riddle" on them—they are worn—the mark underneath is "S P," with the figure 3.

PATRICK KELLEY (police-constable M 36.) I went with Mr. Riddle to the house, and searched a back-room on the ground-floor—I did not find any thing there—I went into the wash-house—we came down from up stairs—I was standing in the passage—Parker came down, and went into the room—she came out, and attempted to go out—I stopped her.
JOHN CHANNER (police-constable M 24.) I went to the house—I did not hear Parker say any thing.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

294.
JOHN MAHONEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of November, 8 horse-shoes, value 6s.; 1 pair of pincers, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 pair of hames, value 4s.; the goods of
Benjamin Whitley, his master.

SAMUEL WRIGHT (police-constable P 172.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 13th of November at his master's shop—I told him it was for robbing his master of some horse-shoes—he said he had not—I searched him and could find nothing on him—I told him I must search his house —he said I should find nothing there belonging to his master—I took him with me to his house in Regent-street, Peckham—I first searched the coal-cellar or cupboard which is by the side of the sitting-room—I there found a pair of pincers and a pair of hames which his master identified—I then went up into the back-room—there was a bedstead pushed against the cupboard-door—I told him I must have the bedstead away to search the cupboard—he said it was no use, there was nothing there, but I moved it, and searched the cupboard and found eight horse-shoes—he said to his master, "They are your property, and I am sorry for it"—nothing was said to induce him to make the statement—he said it voluntarily.
Prisoner. I had not been at work that week—I had a bad hand—he
came and said he had information that I sold shoes and iron—I said they were my master's—I took them out on Saturday night, and sometimes take them to my house.

BENJAMIN WHITLEY . The prisoner has been in my service about three years. On the 13th of November he was taken into custody—I was present when he was searched at the shop—10s. was found on him which he afterwards admitted was my property—I went to search his house with the policeman, we searched the coal-cupboard, and the first thing found was a pair of pincers, which were mine—when they were first brought out the prisoner said he had had them for years—I said I could swear to them—he then admitted they were mine—I had asked him for them several times within the last three months, and he said he knew nothing of them—the next articles found were a pair of names—he said he had them by him for years—I said they were mine—they belonged to a person named Bates, who had sent them to be repaired—he then said, "They are your property, master, I did not know they were there"—I searched up stain— we searched all round the bed—the policeman said he must have the bed moved to search the cupboard and the bed—the prisoner's wife was stand
ing by the side of the cupboard putting the child to sleep, she moved, and the cupboard was opened—the prisoner objected to the bed being moved, and said there was nothing more—I swear she said so—imme
diately the officer opened the cupboard he pulled out eight horse-shoes, and said, "Here is something here"—I said, "That is some of the things I have been looking after for a long time"—the prisoner said, "They are yours, master, I hope you won't give me in charge, if yon will let me go I will not show my face any more," as he was sure I should not employ him any more after that, and he would sell all he had and pay me whatever I demanded—I said it was out of my bands, I could not take any part in it—I gave him in charge—we went directly to the station-house—on the Monday following we went to Union-hall—before we had been before the Magis
trate the officer came to me and said the prisoner admitted it was my money—the prisoner said he had received the money that was in his posses
sion from Camden-lodge, which is a place where I shoe horses, and he meant to pay me—he was not employed to shoe horses on the Monday morning.

Prisoner. They were horses in the back fields. Witness. He was not employed there—he was not able to do anything on Saturday night, he was lame—it was part of his duty to do that work on Saturday night or Monday morning—they were brickmakers' horses—he used to take shoes from my place for that purpose—he used to shoe their horses every week—he used to look round to see if anything was wanted—he generally knew the week previous, or on the Friday, what was wanted—he bad been lame, and another man was employed to do the work that week.

Prisoner. My master knew the shoes were in my house three weeks; I never could get an opportunity of putting them on. Witness. I had no knowledge whatever that he kept shoes by him longer than from Sa
turday night to Sunday morning—he generally took them from the shop on Sunday morning—he was to come to the shop and take what was wanted—I remember, three weeks previous to his being taken, that Smith's omnibus broke down, and it had a new spring made to it—I know of no shoes being taken from the shop that evening; but it is very probable they were.

Prisoner. I took the shoes when it suited me, because I had to put them on; it was my duty to keep them in repair, and so long as I did it he did not know when it was done; I never sold a shoe belonging to him, or wronged him or a halfpenny.

THOMAS CLARIDGE . I am a dealer in marine-stores. On the 3rd or 4th of November the prisoner offered me some new horse-shoes to sell—there might be upwards of a dozen—I have known him several years—he went by the name of Mike.

Prisoner. I could take my solemn oath I have not seen that man for four or five years; he never came into my house. Witness. You know I have; and this conversation was in your own house, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning; I have seen you five hundred times in the last five years; your house is No. 4, Regent-street.
COURT. Q. How came you to go to his house? A. I keep a shop, but I go round to purchase articles, and the prisoner called me as I went past.

BENJAMIN WHITLEY
re-examined. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of being away from you from nine to ten o'clock? A. Yes, very fre
quently.

JURY. Q. Do not you know that he often took shoes from your shop on Sunday morning, to shoe these horses? A. Not without my know
ledge, unless I was out—I have trusted him to take them to the brick-fields, but never to keep any by him, because I always kept a stock at the stable at the brick-field—he was employed by me from the 1st to the 8th of November—he was attending his work as usual—Claridge did not come to me to make this statement—the officer gave me the information—I went to Claridge's shop on the evening the prisoner was taken—I had information about a fortnight before from quite another party—these pin
cers would be necessary if he were going to put on horse-shoes—I had missed the pincers about four months—I am confident that these names were on my premises—they are repaired—they had been missing six months—I should not have known they were lost if I had not found them—here is a swivel on them which I can swear to—I observed to the prisoner at the time, that it was not worth putting on—these shoes were made for a horse that treads very hard, and here is a piece of steel put on the shoe, and here is a particular mark on this.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

295.
WILLIAM BURTON STEWARTSON was indicted
for steal
ing, on the 2nd of October, 1 sovereign, 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 3 sixpences, and 3 groats:—also, on the 9th of October, 1 sovereign, 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 3 sixpences, and 3 groats:—also, on the 16th of October, 1 sovereign, 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 3 six-pences, and 3 groats:—also, on the 6th of November, 1 sovereign, 2 crowns, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3 groats; and, on the 13th of November, 1 sovereign, 2 crowns, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3 groats; the monies of
Thomas Henry Maudsley and others, his masters; to all of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Years.

296.
ANN JONES was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

297.
LEVI THOMAS and
WILLIAM M'CLIVE were indicted for
feloniously and piratically stealing, on the 13th of May, upon the high seas, within the jurisdiction of the Admiralty of England, 1 boat, value 19l.; 3 oars, value 1l. 4s.; 1 sail, value 2l. 10s.; 1 cask, value 1l. 6s.; 20 fa
thorn of rope, value 15s.; the goods of
John Temperley and others: 1 watch, value 1l., the goods of
Samuel Jefferson: 2 shirts, value 10s.; 2 woollen shirts, value 12s.; 1 jacket, value 1l.; and 2 pairs of trowsers, value 2l. 12s.; the goods of
John Buurmester.
MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL JEFFERSON . I was mate on hoard the barque Jane, which laid off a port of Mexico, in May last—she was an English vessel, and had sailed from Liverpool—the prisoners both belonged to the ship—one of the seamen gave me information in May last, in consequence of which I looked about and missed a boat, and four men of the vessel were gone—the prisoners are two of them—I also missed some oars, a top-gal-lant studding sail, a cask, my own watch, and some clothes belonging to two seamen—I had been on deck myself till eleven o'clock the night before, and left the prisoner Thomas on deck in charge of the watch—the other prisoner was below—the master of the vessel had been on shore some days—the captain made a communication to the English consul of what had occurred—I am sure the prisoners are two of the men.
Thomas. Q. You gave the watch in my charge when you went below? A. Yes, I was in the habit of doing it—it was a small silver watch.

COURT. Q. Who had charge of the vessel in your absence? A. He had during the two hours of his watch—I have seen it safe since—(pro
duced) —this is it.
M'Clive. We did not steal any clothing from the vessel, it is a mistake. Witness. Two of the men complained of losing their clothes.

JOHN BUURMESTER . I was a seaman on board the barque Jane—I remember when she laid off the port—I was on deck about nine o'clock—Thomas came up to me and said, "You are a dead man"—in consequence of that I went below—I went up on deck again about three o'clock in the morning—four men were then gone from the vessel—the pri
soners are two of them—the boat and sails, cask and other things were gone from the vessel, which were on board when I went below—the boat was on board, lying aft, when Thomas said, "You are a dead man"—I missed a jacket, waistcoat, two pairs of trowsers, and four shirts, of my own.
Thomas. Q. Did you see me take anything belonging to the ship? A. No—it was not Jackson that told me if I did not go down I should be a dead man.
M'Clive. Q. You did not see me take any of your clothes? A. No—Jackson was one of the four men that went.

JOHN TEMPERLEY . I was master of the barque Jane, and am part owner of her with others—the value of my property taken from the vessel is about 40l.—the boat was worth nineteen guineas—I have not recovered any part of it—I was on shore at the time—the vessel was sixteen miles

from shore, on the high seas—in consequence of a communication from the Admiralty, I went to Cork, and found the two prisoners in custody—I saw this watch there—it was given to Roe by the Cork constable.
JOHN ROE . I am an officer. The watch was handed to me by the Cork officer at Guildhall—I was not at Cork—the officer is not here.

Thomas's Defence. I was taken from the ship into the boat in conse
quence of being in liquor; the apprentice had given me liquor, and I did not know where I was till next day; I laid in the bottom of the boat all night, till next day, when I told Jackson I wished to be put on board my ship again; he said it was impossible; I was landed on the Spanish main, and when I got back, the ship was gone; I delivered myself up to the Spanish Consul, and said I had the mate's watch, and delivered it up. I knew nothing of its being taken from the ship till next day.

JOHN TEMPERLEY
re-examined. I first heard of them about the 18th of May—the boat was taken between the 11th and 16th—I heard nothing of them till they got to Cork, but they were arrested by the Consul—Jack
son was also arrested, and broke out of prison.
Q. Was there any allowance on board to make him intoxicated? A. The only complaint in the ship was for the want of that allowance—I do not know how the prisoners were taken.

SAMUEL JEFFERSON
re-examined. Thomas was perfectly sober at eleven o'clock at night, and there was no means of his getting any thing after-wards—Jackson was not so powerful a man as Thomas—he had been sick with ague.
Thomas. I had one bottle of brandy, and one of rum given me by Williams and a boy on board besides, they had some gin in a bowl three parts full.

THOMAS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

M'CLIVE—
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: ADJOURNED TO THE 13TH DAY OF DECEMBER.
